loans.name: Blanca Flor

texts.es:
Blanca es una madre de familia de 52 años de edad que reside junto a su esposo y a su hijo en el caserío Guaraguaos del distrito agrícola de Tambogrande, una zona agrícola situada en la región Piura, a más de cuatro horas de la ciudad de Chiclayo, capital de la región Lambayeque.

Se dedica a la crianza y comercialización de ganado ovino en la parte posterior de su domicilio y cuando estos ya han alcanzado un buen nivel de desarrollo las ofrece en venta a los negociantes que suelen visitar la zona en donde reside. Esta actividad la realiza hace 6 años. Adicionalmente es agricultor siembra mango y cacao.

El desea adquirir alimentos balanceado y animales, asi también comprar fertilizantes para su cultivo. Por ello ha creído conveniente solicitar a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1500 nuevos soles.
texts.en:
Blanca, age 52, is a mother of a family who lives with her husband and her son in the Guaraguaos settlement of the Tambogrande district -- an agricultural district located in the Piura region, more than four hours away from the city of Chiclayo, which is the capital of the Lambayeque region.

Blanca makes her living by raising and commercializing sheep livestock. She raises the animals in the backyard of her home and when they reach a good level of development, she offers them for sale to the merchants who visit the area. She has been in this business for over six years. In addition, she also grows mango and cacao.

Blanca would like to purchase livestock and balanced animal feed as well as manure for her crops. That is why she decided to ask Edpyme Alternativa for a loan of 1500 soles.

loans.use: to purchase livestock and balanced animal feed

loans.name: Pum

texts.en: Pum N., 50, is a local rice farmer who has been working in this sector since 2002. She and her husband grow rice on their own farmland. They also harvest and sell their mature produce around three months after they began planting. From this business, they can generate an income of around $2 USD a day. This humble couple has five single children and one married child. Currently, Pum N. hopes to grow various crops on her own land. Due to insufficient funds, she has decided to seek a loan to purchase farming materials such as seeds, fertilizer, and other supplies to begin a new farming business.

loans.use: to purchase farming materials such as seeds, fertilizer, and other supplies to begin a new farming business.

loans.name: Chanthoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanthoeun is a widow with five children, two of whom are laborers. The others are studying in the local public school. She was born in 1965. She cuts leaves of palm trees to make rooves for sale and she is a tailor and a farmer.  She owns a very small piece of land where she grows rice to support for her own family. Although she tries to work hard, she can earn little income.  

To improve this condition, Mrs. Chanthoeun is applying for a loan to add to her savings so that she can buy a cow for breeding to start a new business.

loans.use: to buy a cow

loans.name: Yan

texts.en: Mrs. Yan is married to Mr. Soem. Both of them are farmers who own a small piece of land where they grow rice for their own family and to sell. They are also chicken breeders. They support a child who is a seamstress in a garment factory. In order to improve their living conditions, they want to start a new business. They need some money to support this business. Mrs. Yan is asking for a loan to buy a cow for breeding.

loans.use: to buy a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Ren

texts.en: Mrs. Ren was born in 1953. She is a widow with two children who are seamstresses in garment factories. She is a pork seller in her village, earning some profit to support her family. Besides this, she is a farmer who owns a half-hectare plot of land to grow rice for her own family. Currently, she wants to start a new business, but she does not have enough money to support it. So, for this purpose, Mrs. Ren is applying for a loan to buy a cow for breeding.

loans.use: to buy a cow.

loans.name: Neng

texts.en:
Mrs. Neng is married to Mr. Mey. She was born in 1972.  They have one child who is attending local public school. They are farmers who own a plot of land where they grow rice to support for their own family. Besides farming, they are rice middlemen and fishermen. 

Although they try to work a lot, they can earn only a little income. So to improve their family's living standard, Mrs. Neng is applying for a loan to buy a cow for breeding to start a new business.

loans.use: To buy a cow.

loans.name: Ni Ketut

texts.en:
Ni Ketut K., 31, is married and has two children. She works as a farmer and earns an average income of Rp. 1,000,000 per month. She applied for a loan of Rp. 5,000,000 to buy fertilizer for cocoa, bananas and beans in her garden, so the plants will have more fruit. In addition to buying chemical fertilizer, she also uses organic fertilizer to maintain the natural preservation. 

Ni Ketut K. plans to save the benefits that will result from her farming for the future of her children. Ni Ketut K. lives with her husband and two children. Her children still attend school. Ni Ketut K. spends Rp. 30,000 for kitchen expenses every day. This is her first loan with MUK.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer.

loans.name: Nub

texts.en: Nub C., 32, is married and resides in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. C. and her husband sell palm sugar, earning an income of about USD 2 each per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 46 on food and USD 31 on the other necessary expenses. C. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase a motorbike with a trailer attached to transport coconuts to resell. This will be her second from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike with a trailer attached to transport coconuts.

loans.name: Mr. Heang Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan consists of fifteen people. Each member’s portion of the loan will be used for different purposes in order to improve their own family's standard of living. Mr. Heang is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. He was born in 1965. He is a farmer who owns a small piece of land where he grows rice to support his own family and he is a village chief. His wife is a pig breeder and a weaver. Since his wife’s business is going well, he wants it to expand. So, Mr. Heang is seeking a loan to buy more silk. He is the father of two children. They are studying at the local public school.

loans.use: To buy more silk

loans.name: Pum

texts.en: Pum H., age 31, is a local rice farmer who has been working in this sector since her children were very young. Currently, she owns a piece of land on which she cultivates different kinds of crops to earn a living. Her husband helps her in the business. She is married with two school-age kids. They generate around $2 US each day to cover the family’s expenses. Pum H. will use this loan to grow watermelons for extra income.

loans.use: to grow watermelon.

loans.name: Mom

texts.en: Mom B., 22, is married and resides in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-angkorean temples. B. is employed at the factory, earning an income of about USD 2 per day. Her husband produces rice wine and is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of USD 3 per month. Each month, the family has to spend USD 50 on food and USD 44 on the other necessary expenses. B. is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase a new motorbike for her husband to operate his business more efficiently. This will be her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy a new motorbike for her husband to operate his business more efficiently.

loans.name: Ourn

texts.en: Ourn B., 48, is married and resides in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-angkorean temples. B. sells vegetables, earning an income of about USD 5 per day. Her husband is a farmer who earns an income of USD 0.5 per month. Each month, the family has to spend USD 66 on food and USD 50 on the other necessary expenses. B. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase more vegetables to expand her current business. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy more vegetables to expand the business.

loans.name: Meng

texts.en: From Ornlong Veng district of Siem Reap province, Meng K. sells a few items such as sweets for kids, gasoline, soft drinks and some cooking supplies, in front of her house. To meet the family’s living expenses, her husband grows different kinds of crops on his own land. This couple has three school-aged children. Recently, part of Meng K.’s stock has run out; she wants to resupply and is requesting a loan to build up her inventory so she can continue selling. With the remainder of the funds, she will support her husband's farming business.

loans.use: To buy more stock and to support her husband's farming business.

loans.name: Mr. Pisith Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Eleven members make up this village bank loan. The group members have selected Mr. Pisith as the village bank president. They will each use their portion of the loan for different purposes to improve their family's standard of living. 

Mr. Pisith was born in 1977. He is a farmer who owns a plot of land where he grows rice to support his own family and to sell. He is also a teacher in the local school while his wife, Mrs. Pheoun, is a seamstress in a garment factory. Currently he has some problems because his house is not comfortable to live in. To improve this situation, Mr. Pisith is asking for a loan to buy zinc and timber to fix his house. He will use the rest of the loan to buy some piglets for breeding to start a new business. 

He is the father of three children: two are attending the local public school and the other is too yoU. to work or study.

loans.use: To buy zinc and timber to fix his house

loans.name: Vun

texts.en: Vun S., 55, is married and resides in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-angkorean temples. S. is a traditional weaver, earning an income of about USD 1.3 per day. Her husband is employed to transport goods to the city, earning an income of USD 5 per month. Each month, the family has to spend USD 28 on food and USD 40 on the other necessary expenses. S. is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase a new truck for her husband to replace the old one. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy a new truck for her husband to replace the old one.

loans.name: Svay

texts.en: Svay C., 27, is married and resides in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-angkorean temples. C. is employed at the factory, earning an income of about USD 2.5 per day. Her husband is a blacksmith, earning an income of USD 5 per month. Each month, the family has to spend USD 28 on food and USD 40 on the other necessary expenses. C. is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase a new motorbike to commute to work. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy a new motorbike to commute to work.

loans.name: Seng

texts.en: Seng L., 55, is married and resides in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-angkorean temples.  L. sells groceries, earning an income of about USD 2.5 per day.  Her husband produces rice wine and raises pigs, earning an income of USD 3 per month.  Each month, the family has to spend USD 28 on food and USD 65 on the other necessary expenses.  L. is requesting a loan of USD 875 to purchase a new motorbike for her family's use. This will be her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for her family's use.

loans.name: Mrs. Vanny Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan is made up of nine people. Mrs. Vanny is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. Each member’s portion of the loan will be used for different purpose in order to improve their family’s standard of living.   

Mrs. Vanny was born in 1971. She is married to Mr. Thy. They are farmers who own a small piece of land where they grow rice and sugar cane to support their own family and to sell. They are also chicken breeders. She faces a problem in the sugar cane field in that the soil is infertile. So, to improve her sugar cane production, Mrs. Vanny is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer. 

She is the mother of four children: one is a seamstress in a garment factory, two are construction workers and the other one is attending the local public school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Thun

texts.en: Thun T., 40, is married and resides in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-angkorean temples. T. produces rice wine and raises pigs, earning an income of about USD 3 per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of USD 4 per month. Each month, the family has to spend USD 45 on food and USD 40 on the other necessary expenses. T. is requesting a loan of USD 600 to purchase more pigs to raise for sale. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy more pigs to raise for sale.

loans.name: Chea

texts.en: Chea S. earns an income by providing sewing services to her neighbors. She has been running this sewing business for over two years. She can sew both traditional cloth and modern cloth. She makes about $3 profit per day to put towards her daily expenses. The other financial earner is her husband who is a gas seller in Ang Snoul district, which is not far from Phnom Penh City. Her husband’s business is growing smoothly because he has good communication skills in dealing with his valued clients. Currently, he wishes to expand his gas selling, but he faces a financial problem. To overcome this obstacle, Chea S. would like to ask for a loan from Kiva for her husband to use to stock up on gas in his store for future sales. The couple is blessed with two single children who are still enrolled at the local school.

loans.use: to buy more stock of gas for her husband's gas selling business

loans.name: Mrs. Savath Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan consists of ten members. They will each use their portion of the loan for different purposes in order to improve their family’s standard of living. Mrs. Savath is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. She was born in 1969. She is a widow with seven children. Three of her children are seamstresses in garment factories while the others attend the local public school. She is a Khmer cake seller and a chicken breeder who is able to earn some profit with which to support her family. Although she tries to work hard, she can only earn a small income. To improve this situation, Mrs. Savath is applying for a loan to add to her savings to buy a cow for breeding to start a new business.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Sourn

texts.en: Sourn S., 33, is married and resides in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-angkorean temples. S. is employed at the factory, earning an income of about USD 3 per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of USD 5 per month. Each month, the family has to spend USD 45 on food and USD 40 on the other necessary expenses. S. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase a new motorbike for her husband to operate his business more efficiently. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy a new motorbike for her husband's business.

loans.name: Pich's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Pich is the group leader. She was selected by the six members of the group loan. Each member’s portion of the loan will be used for different purposes in order to improve their family’s standard of living. 

Mrs. Pich was born in 1981. She is married to Mr. Phorn. Both of tH. are farmers who own a small piece of land where they can grow both rice and vegetables to support their own family and to sell. In addition, they are pig breeders. Since her business is getting on well, she wants to expand. Mrs. Pich would like a loan to buy more some piglets and pig food for breeding. 

She is a mother of two children. They are too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy piglets and pig food

loans.name: Hem

texts.en: Hem S., 43, is married and resides in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-angkorean temples. S. sells groceries, earning an income of about USD 5 per day. Her husband produces hand-made-brooms to sell, earning an income of USD 5 per month. Each month, the family has to spend USD 45 on food and USD 40 on the other necessary expenses. S. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase a new motorbike for the children to commute to work. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for her children who will use it to commute to work.

loans.name: Svay

texts.en: Svay P., 48, is married and resides in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-angkorean temples. P. and her husband are farmers, earning an income of about USD 1 each per day. Three of her children are employed at the factory, earning an income of USD 3 each per month. Each month, the family has to spend USD 45 on food and USD 60 on the other necessary expenses. P. is requesting a loan of USD 800 to purchase a new motorbike for the children to commute to work. This will be her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for the children to commute to work.

loans.name: Nget

texts.en: Mrs. Nget was born in 1969. She is a shoe-making laborer who earns some money to support her family. Her husband is a government worker. Currently, she has an obstacle because her husband’s work place is far away from their house. So to improve this condition, Mrs. Nget would like to seek a loan to add to her savings to buy a new motorcycle for transport. She is a mother of three children. One of the children is a seamstress in a garment factory; the others are attending a local public school.

loans.use: To buy a new motorcycle

loans.name: Tin

texts.en:
Tin A., a 37-year-old merchandise trader in the busy local market for over five years, sells items such A. cooking materials and groceries, earning US$10 a day. The mother of a young school-aged child dependent on her income, Tin wA. married but divorced her husband many years ago.

Customer patronage of Tin A.’s business is growing steadily, so in order to meet customer demand she is requesting a loan of US$ 600 from Kiva to purchase additional cooking supplies and grocery items.

loans.use: to buy additional cooking supplies and grocery items.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase additional groceries to sell.

loans.name: Yoeurn

texts.en:
Mrs. Yoeurn, who was born in 1964, is married to Mr. Mean.  They have six children. Two of the children are seamstresses in garment factories, one is a construction worker, and the others are studying in the local public school. 

Mrs. Yoeum and her husband are farmers who own a 1-hectare plot of land where they can grow rice to support their own family.  They are also chicken breeders.  Although they try to work hard, they can earn little income.  To improve this condition, Mrs. Yoeurn is seeking a loan to buy a cow for breeding to start a new business.

loans.use: to buy a cow for breeding

loans.name: Heang

texts.en:
Mrs. Heang was born in 1955. She is married to Mr. Nou. They have five children: one is employed in a restaurant, one is employed for a private company, another is a seamstress in a garment factory, and the others are studying in a local public school. 

Mrs. Heang and her husband are farmers who own a small piece of land where they grow rice for their own family. She is also a chicken breeder and a silk weaving laborer. At present, she has an obstacle because her house is too old to live in. So, to improve this condition, Mrs. Heang would like a loan to buy timber for fixing her house. Her husband is in the photo with her.

loans.use: to buy timber.

loans.name: Hurelbaatar

texts.en: Hurelbaatar is 41 years old and lives with his wife and two children in a ger, Mongolian traditional nomadic housing tent in Hovd province, Mongolia. His son and daughter, ages 13 and 14, both attend local secondary school. Hurelbaatar manages a coal trading business in his town. He started his business in 2008 with the help of his younger brother. They bring buyers coal from countryside area. In addition to his coal trading business he conducts a vegetable planting business in his town. His two businesses are the main source of income for their family. He is a polite man who says, "I am trying hard to deposit money for my children's education." He is requesting a 500,000 MNT of loan to purchase seeds and some equipment for his vegetable planting business.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and some equipment.

loans.name: Mrs. Nhan Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of ten members who will each use their portion of the loan for different purposes to improve their family’s standard of living. Mrs. Nhan is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. She was born in 1972. She is a farmer who owns a 1.5-hectare plot of land where she grows rice to support her own family and to sell. She also breeds chickens.

It is time to farm the rice field and she needs some money to support this activity. To improve her rice production, Mrs. Nhan is applying for a loan to buy rice seed, fertilizer and pesticide. With the rest of the loan she is going to plow her own field. Her husband is a construction worker. Through these activities, they support three children who are studying at the local public school.

loans.use: To buy rice seed, fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: Erdenee

texts.en: Erdenee is 40 years old and lives with his wife and three children in their own house in Zavhan province, Mongolia. His daughter and two sons, age 9, 13 and 15, all attend local secondary school. He manages a clothes trading business with the help of his wife. He started his business in 2000 with working capital of 1,000,000 MNT. He travels to China once in a month in order to import his goods. He managed to build a good relationship both with his customers and suppliers. Now his working capital has reached 2,500,000-3,000,000 MNT. He is a diligent man who says, "I never borrowed money from bank before. But I think that if one will use the loan wisely it is good thing for business expansion." He is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT to buy summer clothes and increase his business sales.

loans.use: to buy summer clothes to sell.

loans.name: Tseepilmaa

texts.en: Tseepilmaa is 43 years old and lives with her three children in a ger, Mongolian traditional nomadic housing tent in Zavhan province, Mongolia. Her two children are employed while one is a student. She manages a clothing trading business in her town. She started her business in 1992 with working capital of 500,000 MNT. She worked hard to stabilize her business and now her working capital has reached 1,500,000-2,000,000 MNT. She built a strong customer base and is planning to continue her business in the future. She is a diligent woman who attributes her business success to her good managerial skill. She says, "I am thankful to Xacbank for lending me required amount of loan for my business." She is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT of loan to purchase clothes from China.

loans.use: To purchase clothes from China to sell.

loans.name: Mr. Kha Village Bank Group

texts.en: Fourteen members make up this village bank loan. They will each use their portion of the loan for different purposes to improve their family’s standard of living. Mr. Kha is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. He is a farmer who owns a 2-hectare plot of land where he grows rice to support his own family and to sell. His wife, Mrs. Horn, is a recycling seller. In the rice field, he faces some problems because it is time for growing. To improve his rice production, Mr. Kha is applying for a loan to buy rice seed and pesticide, and to plow his rice field. He will use the rest of the loan to buy more recycled goods to resell. He is the father of four children: one is a farmer and the others are studying at the local public school.

loans.use: To buy rice seed and pesticide, and to plow his rice field

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Gemma M. is from the town of Sta. Rosa, Gamu, Ilagan, Isabela. She is 42 years old. Gemma is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Gemma owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling food products in the local community. Gemma has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Gemma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gemma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Gemma is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, coffee, sugar, rice and bread to sell. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Gemma from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods, coffee, sugar, rice and bread to sell

loans.name: An

texts.en:
An H., 38, and her husband, 42, earn a daily income by growing rice, the most important and widespread occupation in Cambodia. The parents of two school-aged children, they also raise some piglets behind their house for extra income and now earn a daily profit of around $3.75 to support the entire family’s daily needs.

Because pig-raising is An H.’s major means to earn money for her family, she is requesting a loan from Kiva project partner HKL to buy some pig food and piglets as well as some products for her grocery business.

loans.use: to buy some pig food and piglets and to support her grocery business.

loans.name: Erdenebat

texts.en: Erdenebat is 44 years old and lives with his wife and three children in a ger, Mongolian traditional nomadic housing tent in Zavhan province, Mongolia. His older two daughters attend local secondary school while the youngest son is in kindergarten. He manages a taxi service business in his town. In addition to his business his wife manages a movie renting business too. His wife is planning to continue and expand her business in the future. Erdenebat is a polite and hardworking man who says, "We are both very thankful to Xacbank for supporting our business and lending us necessary amount of money." He is requesting a 2,500,000 MNT of loan to purchase players, DVDs and CDs in order to support his wife's business.

loans.use: To purchase DVDs and CD players for his wife's movie renting business.

loans.name: Aisuluu's Group

texts.en:
Aisuluu S. K. is the leader of this group. She is 37 and resides in Nookat, a small village in Osh region. Unfortunately she is a widow. She has three sons, the first son studies at university and the other two are at school. Ten years ago with the initial investment of 2000 soms Aisuluu started to sell grocery products. In ten years she achieved good results, her monthly profit is 10000 soms and this profit made is possible for her to build a kiosk, a shed and a summer kitchen. She hopes to obtain the loan because she needs money to purchase more grocery goods, such as: macaronis, sugar, various drinkings  in order to increase the turnover of her business. In the future Aisuluu wants to provide her children a good education.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase inventory for the grocery store

loans.name: Mrs. Yoem Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Yoem is a village bank president who has beE. selected by the fifteE. members of this village bank loan. Each member’s portion of the loan will be used for different purposes to improve their family’s standard of living.  

Mrs. Yoem was born in 1953. She is married to Mr. Lorn. They are farmers who own a 1.10-hectare plot of land where they grow rice to support their own family and to sell. He is a sugar palm collector and a cow middleman. Although they try to work hard, they can only earn a small income. To improve this situation, Mrs. Yoem is seeking a loan to buy two piglets and some chickens, and to build a pigsty to start a new pig breeding business. She is the mother of one child who is a farmer.

loans.use: To buy two piglets and some chickens, and to build a pigsty for breeding

loans.name: Munhbat

texts.en: Munhbat is 41 years old and lives with his wife and four children in a ger, Mongolian traditional nomadic housing tent in Zavhan province, Mongolia. His older two daughters and son attend local secondary school while the youngest one is in kindergarten. He manages a vegetable trading business with the help of his wife. He started his business in 1982. They plant their vegetable during spring period and sell them in fall. They own 50 hectare of land and a big storage too. They gained much experience and became well-known amongst their customers. Munhbat is a hardworking man who says, "I am borrowing loan many times from Xacbank. I will do my best to pay back the loan on time." He is requesting a 1,200,000 MNT of loan to purchase potatoes and some equipment for his business.

loans.use: To purchase potatoes and some equipment.

loans.name: Mrs. Malin Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan consists of fifteen people who will use their portions of the loan for different purposes in order to improve their families' standard of living. Mrs. Malin is the village bank president selected by the members. She was born in 1979. To earn money to support the family, Mrs. Malin is a chicken breeder and her husband, Mr. Oun, is a key seller in the local market. Since her husband’s business is going well, they want to expand it. Therefore, Mrs. Malin is asking for a loan to buy more keys for resale and to buy two piglets to start a new breeding business. Mrs. Malin is the mother of four children; two are enrolled in the local public school and two are too small to work or study.

loans.use: To buy more keys.

loans.name: Zoljargal

texts.en: Mr. Zoljargal is 30 years old Geologist. He lives with his wife and only son Munkhjin 6, in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Zoljargal works in an "Asian elephant" company as a geologist. His family own a plot of land and a small family house. Zoljargal,s job has a seasonal character and he works as a geologist from April till end of November and in his of season time, he carries people as a taxi using his family car earning some extra money. The house in which he lives is quite old and needs some renovation: completely replacing the floor, putting insulation to the walls and roof and doing interior decoration. By doing this he can save on heating cost and in same time reducing emission of poisonous gases to the air. The recent survey show that Ulaanbaatar city's air quality is in dangerous level, especially in winter time, few times exceeding the normal level. The loan Mr.Zoljargal is requesting will be used to buy insulation materials, laminated floor and other necessary building materials to make the house warmer and well insulated from the cold.

loans.use: To buy insulation materials, laminated floor and other necessary building materials to make the house warmer and well insulated from the cold.

loans.name: Joan

texts.en:
Joan N. is from the town of Sta. Rosa, Gamu, Ilagan, Isabela. She is 36 years old. Joan is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Joan owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a clothing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing general clothing services to local community members. Joan has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Joan joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Joan has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Joan is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional clothing materials to sell. This loan will be the 7th loan taken out by Joan from ASKI.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional clothing materials to sell.

loans.name: Min

texts.en:
A resident of Baray District in Kompong Tom Province, Min S. has been in the farming business for many years. She and her husband often use their existing farmland for cultivating crops at least twice a year following the dry season and rainy season. As well, the couple has been raising a few piglets both for offspring and for slaughter. 

They are the parents of eight unmarried children, three of whom work in jobs requiring them to commute by motor taxi because they don’t have a vehicle. Min is therefore requesting a loan to buy a used motorbike for her children to ride to their workplace. She hopes to use the rest of loan to hire a plowing machine for her farmland so she can start to plant her crops during the dry season.

loans.use: to buy a used motorbike for her children to commute to work and hire a plowing machine for her farmland.

loans.name: Mrs. Sarin Village Bank Group

texts.en:
There are ten people who maK. up this village bank loan.  They will all use their portion of the loan for different purposes in order to improve their family’s standard of living.  

Mrs. Sarin is the village bank president who has been selected by the members.  She was born in 1954.  She is a farmer who owns a 2-hectare plot of land where she grows rice and potatoes to support her own family and to sell.  She is also a chicken breeder while her husband, Mr. Vel, is a construction worker.  Although they try to work hard, they can earn little income.  So to improve this condition, Mrs. Sarin is applying for a loan to buy three piglets and pig food for breeding to start a new business.  She has three children.  They are all studying in the local public school.

loans.use: To buy three piglets and pig food for breeding

loans.name: Ignacio

texts.en:
Ignacio P. is from the town of Sta. Rosa, Gamu, Ilagan, Isabela. He is 42 years old. Ignacio is married and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, Ignacio owns and operates a business venture in the transportation sector providing motorcycle transport services. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from operating tricycle transport services. Ignacio has been engaged in his business for over six years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Ignacio joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Ignacio has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to repair existing vehicle for better service. Ignacio is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase tires and other accessories. This loan will be the 7th loan taken out by Ignacio from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase tires and other accessories for his motorcycle transport service.

loans.name: Dorjnamjil

texts.en: Dorjnamjil is 56 years old and lives with his wife and daughter in a house in Han-Uul district, Ulaanbaatar, capital city of Mongolia. They live with their two disabled relatives and take care of them. Dorjnamjil is a photographer who works at Suhbaatar square, is the central square of Ulaanbaatar city, Mongolia. It is scene of major state ceremonies, cultural events and exhibitions. Therefore many people gather at this square and like to be photographed to keep their precious memories. He started his business in 2001.  In 2004 his wife, Altantsetseg, also began working as a photographer too. His daughter, age 25, helps with the family business by picking up the films in order to process them at a laboratory. They prefer to use advanced cameras in order to provide quality service for their customers. So they began using digital cameras to capture images electronically which allowed them to print their pictures in a minute. They also offered a very special service of taking one's picture with Mongolian traditional clothes on. They are planning to continue and expand their business in the future. Dorjnamjil is a hardworking man who says, "By depositing my business earnings I want to pay the education cost of my daughter." He is requesting a 2,500,000 MNT of loan to renew his camera and to purchase more photo papers.

loans.use: To to renew his camera and purchase more photo papers for his photography business.

loans.name: Mrs. Samun Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village has seventeen members who have selected Mrs. Samun to be the village bank president.  All the members will use their portion of the loan for different purposes in order to improve their family’s standard of living. 

Mrs. Samun was born in 1979.  She is a farmer who owns a plot of land where she can grow rice and potatoes to support her own family and for sale while her husband is a recycling seller.  Since her husband’s business is doing well, she wants to expand it.  So to improve it, Mrs. Samun is applying for a loan to buy more recycled material for resale.  She is a mother of two children.  One of whom is a student, but the youngest one is 3-years-old.

loans.use: To buy more recycled materials for resale

loans.name: Polotbek's Group

texts.en:
Polotbek T. is a member of this group. He is 45 and married. His wife went to work in Russia to make money. Polotbek takes care of three children: a daughter and two sons. The youngest son studies at school and the other children help their dad with housework. Polotbek works as a specialist in the Migration Department.  His monthly salary is 4400 soms.  In order to earn additional money to meet his family needs, Polobek breeds livestock. With the  money received from the loan he wants to purchase sheep for breeding.  In the future Polotbek wants to purchase an apartment for his children.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase sheep for breeding.

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites B. is from the town of Sta. Rosa, Gamu, Ilagan, Isabela. She is 49 years old. Marites is married and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, Marites owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Marites has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Marites joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marites has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock. Marites is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. This loan will be the 7th loan taken out by Marites from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future.

loans.name: Demberel

texts.en: Mrs. Demberel is 43 years old, lives with her only daughter in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They live in their small family house. Her husband works in a factory in South Korea on a labor exchange contract earning some extra income. Mrs.Demberel rents a stall at one of the Ulaanbaatar city’s meat market and runs a meat retail business. She buys meat from the wholesale point at wholesale price, than cleans and cuts them to small parts and sells to customers. She also has a meat supply agreement with two Cafes nearby and delivers there meat on a daily basis. She is planning to buy more meat according to customers' demand and at the same time to raise her income. Until the next school term, she is planning to save some money to pay for her daughter's education fee.

loans.use: To buy more meat to meet customers' high seasonal demand, raise her income, save some money to pay for her daughter's education fees.

loans.name: Sanabar's Group

texts.en:
Sanabar M. is the leader of this group. She is 50 and married, her husband is a pensioner. Together they bring up a daughter, who studies at school. In order to earn money Sanabar takes orders and sews Kyrgyz national blankets, cloth and dressmaking supplies.  A year ago with the initial investment of 5000 soms Sanabar began to sell groceries.  In this way she earns additional 1000 soms per month. The family also breeds livestock animals.  With money received from the loan Sanabar wants to purchase more sheep in order to increase the number of livestock. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase more sheep in order to increase the number of livestock.

loans.name: Reun

texts.en: Reun R., a 60-year-old resident of Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, earns a living by selling groceries such as soft drinks, fast foods, cooked foods and sweets for children in front of her house.  A married woman who currently takes care of two school-aged children, with three other children already married, Reun has been in this business for ten years now. Her husband works as an assistant of the commune chief. Reun is requesting a loan to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.use: to purchase extra grocery inventory to sell.

loans.name: Sahodatkhon's Group

texts.en:
Sahodatkhon T. is the leader of this group.  She is 61 and married, her husband is a pensioner. Together they have raised three sons; all the sons are working in Russia. Sahodatkhon and her husband are farmers. They breed livestock animals and then resell it at the higher price after fattening. In this way they earn additional 1500 soms per month. They also cultivate agricultural products; with money received from the loan Sahodatkhon would purchase potato seeds. In the future she wants to increase the number of livestock and improve the family’s living conditions.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase potato seeds for farming.

loans.name: Toem

texts.en:
Toem L., 52, is a rural villager who lives in Kompong Tom province. Her husband works in construction.

Since 2005, she has made a living raising pigs in a pig stall located near her house on her land. She raises pigs in order to breed them and for meat. She wants to help be responsible for the family’s daily food.  

Besides her pig-raising business, Toem Lum also grows rice on her farmland. 

In previous times, Toem L. has always hired the neighbor’s cow in order to alleviate the chore of plowing the farmland. Right now, she hopes to buy her own cow and that is why she is applying for a loan from Kiva. This will provide her with an additional fixed asset.

loans.use: to buy a cow.

loans.name: Gulnara's Group

texts.en:
Gulnara A. is the leader of this group. She is 27 and married to a security guard. Together with her husband she brings up two daughters; both of them are preschool ages (under seven). Gulnara works as a teacher in a kindergarten. The family is also engaged in cattle breeding. They started this activity five years ago, with the initial investment of 2000 soms. With money received from the loan, Gulnara wants to purchase cattle for breeding. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). loans.name: Ankhbayar

texts.en: Mr. Ankhbayar is 23 years old, lives with his parents and three younger brothers in parents apartment in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Last summer he has graduated from a University of Science and Technology as a bachelor in geology.  Currently he has been employed by a private mining company as a geologist.  He has a seasonal job where he goes to a mining site in the summer and autumn time and is free of work the rest of the time. Last year he earned some money working for this company.  Using his savings, Ankhbayar plans to do some proper renovation to his parents old apartment, but he is short on money. The loan Ankhbayar is requesting will be used to buy necessary building materials such as wall papers, paints, plasters, cements and so on to renovate his parents apartment.

loans.use: To buy necessary building materials such as wall papers, paints, plasters, cements, etc., in order to surprise his parents by renovating their old apartment.

loans.name: Sar

texts.en:
Sar S., 58, lives in Phnom Penh city. She currently lives with her mother who stays at home to care for the housework. She was married with Mr. Sar Theurn, age 56, who is a rice farmer. She has two married children and the other two are single. The three of them earn money to help meet the family's living expenses. 

Sar S.’s children always use their own motorbike as a way to ride to work, but now their motor is broken down. Sar S. doesn’t have  immediate cash to help them, so she has decided to seek a loan to buy a used motorcycle for her children in order to replace the broken one.

loans.use: to buy a used motorcycle for her children in order to replace the broken one.

loans.name: Khoem

texts.en:
Khoem S., 65 years old, is a widow living in the capital, Phnom Penh, in the middle of Cambodia. She is blessed with two children. One is married and the other is single. To share responsibility with Khoem S., one of her children is working as a sewing worker at the garment factory, and she gets a formal salary per month for her sewing. 

To earn a living, Khoem S. sells lotus to people who need it for ceremonies to bless the god. 

This rice harvesting season, Khoem S. wants to purchase many sacks of rice to store in her stock supply. She will sell them later when  rice is commanding the highest price. That is the reason she needs a loan.

loans.use: To buy rice to stock up while price are low for later sale.

loans.name: Florita

texts.en:
Florita A. is from Sta. Rosa, Gamu, Ilagan, Isabela. She is 49 years old. Florita is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Florita owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Florita has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Florita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Florita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand product offerings. Florita is requesting a new loan of 13000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional groceries to sell. This loan will be the 7th loan taken out by Florita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Angelina

texts.en: Angelina is currently in a business of selling green vegetables. She is 40 years old, married, with 4 children and 2 of them go to school. Angelina borrowed a loan to stock more green vegetables to sell. She hopes to expand her business with extra profits in the future.

loans.use: Stock more green vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Artak

texts.en:
Artak A. lives in Yerevan with his wife, parents and daughter. 

Artak is engaged in advertising. He rents an office in the city. Artak’s firm offers services in advertising, event management and branding. 

Artak wants to have online advertising for his firm and develop his business. With the requested loan he plans to buy sites for his advertisement. Artak will have the opportunity to present his services to more target groups, develop his business and get more income.

loans.use: to pay for online advertising.

loans.name: Christine

texts.en: Christine Kasajja lives in the Kisaasi neighbourhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has five children, all of whom are in school.  Christine has a business of selling in a pub.  She has been in this business for 10 years, and she works seven days out of every week. Christine sells her products in a shop, by means of wholesale/retail.  Christine has requested a loan of 600000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will be used to buy more jerycans of local Gin and beer.  The main business challenge(s) for Christine include seasonality and defaulters.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a fully stocked bar.  Christine lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and has access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include rent, paying utility bills and feeding the family.

loans.use: to buy more jerycans of local Gin and more crates of beer to sell.
