La señora agradece a la Fundación Paraguaya por haberle aceptado como clienta de la institución y solicita este préstamo para poder adquirir un stock más variado de mercaderías, es decir, comprar más artículos electrónicos novedosos para la atracción y venta a las personas.
texts.en:
Maria Liz Carina is 29 years old.  She lives with the father of her son 8 month-old Thiago Santiago.  Maria is a saleswoman in the city of Villarrica and owns a well-known business selling and repairing cell phones.  She also sells general electronic gadgets.

Maria's business is well known in her area because of her good stock of merchandise.  She is also known for her good customer service.  Thanks to her charisma, she has a lot of customers.

Maria is grateful to Fundación Paraguaya for having accepted her as a client.  She is requesting this loan so that she can acquire a greater variety of merchandise.  That is to say, she will buy more of the latest electronic appliances to attract customers who she will sell to.

loans.use: to buy electronic appliances

loans.name: Pal

texts.en:
From Baray district of Kompong Tom province, Pal T. is a local rice farmer, and she has been in the farming business for years. She typically generates an income of $1 per day. Her husband earns a profit by driving a plowing machine for his neighbors when they need a machine to plow on their farmland. 

This couple has been married for years and has four children. Two of them are employed as garment workers at the factory and they have formal salaries. 

Pal T. is concerned that she faces difficulties in traveling. She and her husband always travel to anywhere by hiring a motor taxi or walking as they don't have their own vehicle. To solve the problem, Pal T. has requested a loan in the amount of $600 to be used to buy a new motorcycle to provide transportation without hiring a taxi.

loans.use: to buy a new motorcycle.

loans.name: Purevsuren

texts.en:
Purevsuren is 38 years old and lives with his relatives in a house in Gobi-Altai province, Mongolia. He manages a public transportation service business between Gobi-Altai province and Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. 

Purevsuren started his business in 2006. At first he used to drive another person's minibus. By saving his salary he managed to buy his own minibus and began working independently in 2008. He travels four or six times in a month between Gobi-Altai and Ulaanbaatar. He transports 12-14 people for one ride. His business gets profitable during national or school holidays. He is a very safe and reliable driver who became well-known amongst his customers. 

He is a diligent man who says, "All I want is a bright future for me and for my family." He is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase machinery parts for his minibus.

loans.use: To purchase machinery parts

loans.name: Matilde

texts.es:
La Sra. MatilD. B. D. 48 años, está casada con el Sr. Juan R. D. 55 años D. edad, ellos tienen 2 hijos que están cursando sus estudios secundarios.
Doña MatilD. posee una despensa y se dedica a este rubro desD. hace más D. 9 años, aproximadamente desD. el año 2002, ella para obtener el capital necesario para emprender su negocio tuvo que vender su automóvil, así pudieron habilitar una pequeña despensa que con el tiempo fueron ampliando.
En la actualidad tiene una despensa, un copetin y una fotocopiadora; su local se encuentra ubicado estratégicamente cerca del Mercado D. Abasto, lo cual hace que tenga buena concurrencia D. gente y más ingreso.
Ella utilizaría este crédito para comprar más mercaderías (gaseosas, yerbas, vino, leche, caña, azúcar, etc), y mejorar su oferta D. productos.
texts.en:
MatilD. B. is 48 years old and married to 55 year-old Juan R..  They have two children who are in high school.

MatilD. owns a grocery store and has been in this business for more than nine years.  She started her business in around 2002.  In order to have the necessary capital to set up her business, she had to sell her car.  In this way, she was able to set up a small grocery store which, over time, she has expanded.

MatilD. currently has a grocery store, snack bar and a photocopier.  Her business is strategically located near the wholesale food market which means that she gets a lot of customers and more income.

MatilD. will use this loan to buy more merchandise (soda, yerba, wine, milk, brandy, sugar, etc.) and will improve the range of products she sells.

loans.use: to buy more merchandise (soda, yerba, wine, milk, brandy, sugar, etc.)

loans.name: Seab

texts.en:
Seab C. is 36 years old and a resident of Kompong Tom province. She is married and has three children who are single. They still live with Seab C.. Her husband’s name is Lach Mach, and he is a causal construction worker as well as a domestic fisherman.

She earns a living raising pigs in a cage behind her house. She raises pigs for breeding and slaughter and often sells to people who come to buy in bulk at her house.  

Seab C. has applied for a $500 loan from Kiva’s partner HKL in order to purchase additional piglets to raise.

loans.use: to purchase additional piglets.

loans.name: Huralgan

texts.en:
Huralgan is 30 years old.  He lives with his wife in a ger, a  traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent in Bayan-Ulgii province, Mongolia. His wife is unemployed. 

Huralgan manages a transportation-service business in his town. He started his business in 2000. He transports construction materials such as rocks, wood and iron.  He earns 28,000 MNT; about 4200 is the net profit from one ride. He transports material 3-5 times per day. He gained much experience and is planning to continue his business in the future. He is an honest man who attributes his business success to his good communication skills. 

He says, "I am trying hard to better my living condition." He is requesting a 2,500,000 MNT loan to buy tires and to repair some parts of his truck.

loans.use: To buy tires

loans.name: Batjargal

texts.en:
Batjargal is 39 years old.  He lives with his wife and one-year-old daughter in ger, a Mongolian traditional nomadic tent in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His wife is looking after the baby at the moment. 

Batjargal is a plumber, but he has been running a taxi business for 8 years and he likes his current business.  He earns around 300 USDs a month. To improve his family's living condition, Batjargal is planning to build a 50 square-meter family house and has the building project ready. He is going to use his savings but he needs some extra funding. The loan Batjargal is seeking will be used to pay for building materials such as cement, bricks, sand, wood planks, insulation materials and some tools to build the family house.

loans.use: To pay for building materials such as cement, bricks, sand, wood planks, insulation materials and tools to build the family house.

loans.name: Ong

texts.en:
Ong S., 54, is a married woman and the mother of four children, two of whom are married and living independently. The other two are single. 

To make a living, Ong S. and her husband are farmers and they always work together in the farming business. 

Ong S. has begun sowing a new rice crop, but she needs fertilizer. Ong S. is applying for this loan to buy fertilizer so that the family will grow a larger crop. She will also use some percentage of the funds to pay for the documentation fee for her child to work in Thailand.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pay the documentation fee for her child to work abroad.

loans.name: Chhay's Group

texts.en:
Consisting of 11 people, this village bank loan is led by Mrs. Chhay, the village bank president selected by the others members, each of whom will use their portion to support their specific purpose.

Chlyi and her husband are grocery sellers  able to earn a small income to support their famiL. living. Since this business is going well, Mrs. Chhay is requesting a loan to buy more groceries to enlarge her business. This couple has three children: two are seamstresses in the garment factories and one is a grocery seller.

loans.use: to buy more groceries to enlarge her business.

loans.name: Phon

texts.en:
Phon S. is a 44-year-old farmer who lives in Battambang province. Currently, Phon S. lives with three school-aged children and earns a living by growing various crops on their own farmland. 

Her husband works as a vehicle repairman in his community, making a profit of around $3 each day. He also frequently works alongside her on the farm. 

Phon S. is asking for a loan as capital to support her farming business. She will use the loan to purchase some sacks of fertilizer and rice seed.

loans.use: to purchase some sacks of fertilizer and rice seed.

loans.name: Chum's Group

texts.en:
Chosen by the other members, Mrs. Chum is the village bank president for this village bank loan composed of eight people. Mrs. Chum's husband, Mr. Sun, is a Khmer cake seller and fisherman who is able to earn a small income to help support his family. This couple has five children, three of whom are laborers, one a seamstress, and one a farmer.

Mrs. Chum, a farmer who owns a plot of land upon which she grows various vegetables for a living, is now requesting a loan to enable the cultivation of a greater variety of vegetables. She will use the rest of the loan to buy fishing supplies to support her husband's fishing.

loans.use: to cultivate a variety of vegetables.

loans.name: Yean's Group

texts.en:
Ten people make up this village bank loan. Mrs. Yean, a married woman who was born in 1971, is the village bank president. She was selected by the others members. Each member of this village bank will use the money to support their own purpose.

Mrs. Yean's husband, Mr. Seng, was born in 1973. They have two children. One is attending a local school and youngest one is a year old.

They are coffee and drinks sellers who are able to earn a small income to help support their family. Since these businesses are going well, Mrs. Yean would like to ask for a loan to buy more coffee and drinks to enlarge her business.

loans.use: To buy more coffee and drinks to enlarge her business.

loans.name: Chea's Group

texts.en:
This village loan consists of nine members. Mrs. Chea, a married woman who was born in 1971, was selected to be the village bank president by the others members.

Her husband, Mr. Yong, was born in 1978 and is a government worker who is able to earn a small salary to help support his family. This couple has five children. One is a wedding chef, one is a mirror smith, two are attending the local school, and the last one is 4 years old. 

Mrs. Chea earns a living by selling snacks. 

Soon, one of her children is going to get married, but she doesn’t have enough money to support it, so she decided to ask for a loan to help pay for her child's wedding.

loans.use: to help pay for her child's wedding.

loans.name: Ainura's Group

texts.en:
Ainura A. is the leader of this group. She is 31 years old and married to a construction worker. Together with her husband, she is raising a son and two daughters.  The son and the elder daughter are at school.  The second daughter does not yet attend school as she is preschool age (younger than seven). 

The family resides in Tup, a small village in the Isykul region. Five years ago, Ainura’s brother presented her with a calf, and since that moment she has been breeding farm animals.  She sells 11 liters of milk every day, which earns her 2000 soms per month.  With money received from this loan, Ainura wants to purchase three sheep in order to fatten them and resell them at a higher price.

Where Did This Loan Come From?

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). 

MBF is the only microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase sheep

loans.name: Sok's Group

texts.en:
Ten people make up this village bank loan. Mrs. Sok  was selected to be the village bank president by the others members. 

Mrs. Sok is a laborer who is able to earn a small income to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Sok, stays at home. This couple has two children. One is a laborer and one is attending the local school. 

Currently, their house is in need of repair, but they don’t have enough money to repair it. Thus, Mrs. Sok decided to ask for a loan to repair her house.

loans.use: to repair her house.

loans.name: Penh

texts.en: Panh M., 38, is married and resides in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-angkorean temples. M. and her husband are farmers, earning an income of about USD 3 per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 20 on food and USD 50 on other necessary expenses. M. is requesting a loan of USD 750 to purchase more cows to raise for sale. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy cows to raise for sale

loans.name: Yin

texts.en:
From the province of Battambang, Yin P. is a 52-year-old widow who earns a daily income by sewing at home. Yin P. provides her service to her neighbors, sewing both traditional clothes and modern clothes. She runs her business very well and a lot of customers recognize the good service she provides. 

She lives with two children who are employed in a garment factory. 

Yin P. will use her loan to add to her current savings for purchasing a new motorbike because her old motorbike often has broken down during use.

loans.use: to purchase a new motorbike.

loans.name: Sem

texts.en: Sem V., 36, is married and resides in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-Angkorean temples. V. and her husband are farmers, earning an income of about USD 3 each per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 42 on food and USD 50 on other necessary expenses. V. is requesting a loan of USD 650 to purchase more ducks to raise for sale. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy more ducks to raise for sale

loans.name: Urkiya's Group

texts.en:
Urkiya T. is the leader of this group. She resides in Nookat, a small village in Osh region. She is 55 and married to a farmer. Together they have raised three sons; the youngest son studies at school and the other children are married and live with their families. 

Urkiya and her husband are farmers.  The couple cultivates agricultural products and earns money by selling part of the harvest. In this way they earn about 6000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, Urkiya wants to purchase mineral fertilizers and potato seeds for farming.  In the future she dreams of building a big house for her sons.

 Where Did This Loan Come From?

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan.  MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. 

To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase mineral fertilizers and potato seeds

loans.name: Mao's Group

texts.en:
Eleven people make up this village bank loan. Mrs. Mao, a married woman who was born in 1975, was selected to be the village bank president by the others members. 

She and her husband, Mr. Sun, are fishermen who are able to earn a small income to help support their family.  Aside from fishing, they also have a plot of land that they use to grow various vegetables.  

This couple has seven children. Two are laborers, one is farmer, three are attending the local school, and the youngest one is 1 year old.

This couple doesn't have a boat for fishing, so Mrs. Mao would like to ask for a loan to buy a fishing boat.

loans.use: To buy a fishing boat.

loans.name: Kul

texts.en: Kul S., 39, is married and resides in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-Angkorean temples. S. is a teacher, earning an income of about USD 2 per day. Her husband is a school bus driver, earning an income of USD 5 per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 50 on food and USD 50 on other necessary expenses. S. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase more pigs to raise for sale. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy pigs to raise for sale

loans.name: Tserendulam

texts.en:
Tserendulam is 43 years old.  She lives with her husband and 2 children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her husband Batbayar is a house interior decorator and works as a freelancer. Her  family lives in an apartment which they bought using a mortgage.

Tserendulam rents a stall inside the food market where she sells meat products such as sausage. Her relatives run a small sausage workshop from which she buys sausages at wholesale and resells them at the food market. She is in this business for 10 years and has loyal customers.

She plans to use her loan to increase her  stock and add some new meat products made of chicken and pork to sell.

loans.use: To buy more meat products to sell and add some new pork and chicken products to her inventory.

loans.name: Ben

texts.en: Ben K., 29, is married and resides in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-angkorean temples. K. buys chickens to resell, earning an income of about USD 7 per day. His wife sells bamboo at home, earning an income of USD 7 per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 50 on food and USD 60 on the other necessary expenses. K. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase supplies to run a cafe. This will be his first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy supplies to run a cafe

loans.name: Neang's Group

texts.en:
Eight people are forming this village bank loan. Mrs. Neang was selected to be the village bank president by the others members.

Mrs. Neang is a farmer who owns a 2-hectare pL. of land that she uses to grow corn and rice. Her husband, Mr. Keo, is a soldier and fisherman who earns a small salary to support his family. He also helps in his wife farming. This couple has three children. Two are farmers and one is attending a local school.

With her husband's occupations and her farming, Mrs. Neang still earns less income than she needs to support her family. So in order to improve the family’s condition, Mrs.Neang would like to ask for a loan to buy piglets for breeding.

loans.use: To buy piglets for breeding.

loans.name: Nhem

texts.en: Nhem K., 49, is married and resides in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-angkorean temples. K. sells palm juice, earning an income of about USD 6 per day. Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of USD 5 per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 30 on food and USD 20 on the other necessary expenses. K. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to repair her house

loans.name: Kourch

texts.en: Kourch S., 26, is married and resides in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-angkorean temples. S. sells groceries, earning an income of about USD 4 per day. Her husband is employed at the garment factory, earning an income of USD 3 per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 25 on food and USD 30 on the other necessary expenses. S. is requesting a loan of USD 600 to purchase cows to resell. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy cows to resell

loans.name: Run

texts.en:
Run A., age 41, is married to Ha Horn, age 32, who works with her in the farming business, and both of them are shown in the photo. She has three children; one is single, and two are married. Her husband has been earning a living for many years by climbing and tapping the palm trees behind his house. 

Run A. would like to apply for a loan in order to buy some planks to repair her old house and to pay for mending costs. She will use any remainder of the loan towards purchasing pig-feed and piglets to raise so as to get more income to support her family.

loans.use: to buy some planks to repair her old house and to pay for mending costs.

loans.name: Yeoun's Group

texts.en:
Eleven people make up this village bank loan. Mrs. YeO., a married woman who was born in 1971, was selected to be the village bank president by the others members. 

Mrs. YeO. is a farmer who owns a plot of land T. she uses to grow rice for a living. Her husband, Mr. Ky, was born in 1980 and is a laborer who also helps his wife in farming. This couple has six children. Two are laborers, two are attending the local school, and the others two are too young to work.

In order to support her farming, Mrs. YeO. would like to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers, gasoline and pesticides for growing rice.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, gasoline and pesticides for growing rice.

loans.name: Kim

texts.en: Kim S., 39, is married and resides in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-angkorean temples. S. is a farmer, earning an income of about USD 1 per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of USD 4 per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 30 on food and USD 35 on the other necessary expenses. S. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to repair her house

loans.name: Lorn's Group

texts.en:
Five people make up this group loan. Mrs. Lorn, who was born in 1961, was selected to be the group leader B. the others members.

She and her husband, Mr. Cheam, make and sell Khmer cakes to support their family. 

This couple has four children. One is a goldsmith, one is a Khmer cake seller, and the other two are students. 

In order to improve the family’s condition, Mrs. Lorn would like to ask for a loan to buy more rice and Khmer cake supplies to enlarge her business activities.

loans.use: To buy more rice and Khmer cake supplies to enlarge her business activities.

loans.name: Elmira's Group

texts.en:
Elmira B. is the leader of this group. She is 44 and married to a farmer. Together they bring up three children; two daughters and a son. All the children study at school. Four years ago with the initial investment of 25000 soms Elmira started to sell grocery products. She earns 5000 soms per month. This profit has made it possible for her to purchase furniture home and improve her living conditions. With the money received from the loan, Elmira wants to purchase more groceries goods: drinkings, cookies, sugar, milk products in order to increase the turnover of her business. In the future Elmira wants to provide her children a good education.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase inventory for the grocery store

loans.name: Chhem's Group

texts.en:
Eleven people make up this village bank loan. Mrs. Chhem, a married woman who was born in 1979, was selected to be the village bank president by the others members. 

Mrs. Chhem is a coffee and drinks seller. Her husband, Mr. Kao, was born in 1977. He is a soldier who also helps in his wife's business. With their occupations, they are able to earn a small income to support their family. They have three children. Two are attending the local school and the youngest one is too young to study or work. 

Since Mrs. Chhem's business is going well, she wants to expand it, so she would like to ask for a loan to buy more coffee and drinks to enlarge her business.

loans.use: To buy more coffee and drinks to enlarge her business.

loans.name: Chheang's Group

texts.en:
There are 15 people who make up this village bank loan. Mrs. Chheang, a married woman who was born in 1980, is the village bank president. She was selected to be the village bank president by the others members. 

Mrs. Chheang is a grocery and fish seller in a local market. She also has a plot of land that she uses to grow potatoes for a living. Her husband, Mr. Phann, was born in 1975 and is a construction worker who also helps in his wife businesses.
 
With these occupations, they are able to earn a small income to support their four children. Three are attending the local school and the youngest one is 2 years old.

In order to continue her farming, Mrs. Chheang would like to ask for a loan to buy supplies needed to grow potatoes.

loans.use: to buy supplies needed to grow potatoes.

loans.name: Syinat's Group

texts.en:
Syinat O. is the leader of this group. She is 44 and married to a driver. Her husband earns money by transporting passengers from Karabalta to Bishkek.  Together they have raised five daughters. The youngest daughter,10, studies at school.  The older daughter is 22, and she is married and lives separately with her husband.  Syinat is engaged in agriculture, she earns money by selling milk, fruits and vegetables. In this way she earns 3600 soms per month. She hopes to obtain the loan because she needs money to purchase fuel and a variety of seeds for farming. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase fuel and a variety of seeds.

loans.name: Rom

texts.en: Rom S., 30, is married and resides in Battambong province, Cambodia, an area known for quality rice products. S. and her husband sell souvenirs, earning an income of about USD 15 per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 45 on food and USD 38 on the other necessary expenses. S. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase souvenirs. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy more souvenirs to sell and expand the business.

loans.name: Creativas 1 & 2 Group

texts.en:
Maritza lives in Santo Domingo, in one of the poorest communities surrounding the main city of the Dominican Republic. Maritza and her group of 10 members are taking loans for their businesses. This group is named Creativas 1 & 2 (Creatives).

Maritza requires a loan to buy fruit and vegetables. She also wants to buy a big box of second hand clothes. She runs a fruit and vegetables stall in front of her house, and she also sells second hand cloths by walking. She has had her business for over 6 years, after a friend gave her a loan to buy vegetables, and after some months she decided to sell fruit.  After hearing from Esperanza, she saw the opportunity to start selling second hand clothes. Her most difficult challenges have been to overcome economy crisis, and low income. She is mom of 4 children.

She says that her favorite thing is to work, and she wants to attend to the church. Maritza and her group are thankful for your support!

loans.use: to buy vegetables, fruits, and second hand clothes.

loans.name: Nith

texts.en: Nith B., 45, is married and resides in Battambong province, Cambodia, an area known for quality rice product. B. and her husband sell Chinese noodles and food, earning an income of about USD 10 per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 45 on food and USD 50 on the other necessary expenses. B. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase more supplements to expand her food selling business. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy more supplements to expand her food selling business.

loans.name: San

texts.en: San S., 32, is married and resides in Battambong province, Cambodia, an area known for quality rice product. S. and her husband are singers for a restaurant, earning an income of about USD 4 each per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 60 on food and USD 50 on the other necessary expenses. S. is requesting a loan of USD 700 to purchase a motorbike to commute to work. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike to commute to work.

loans.name: Mov's Group

texts.en:
Twelve people make up this village bank loan. Mrs. Mov, who was born in 1961, was selected as the village bank president by the others members. 

Mrs. Mov is widow with a child who is seamstress in a garment factory.
 
Mrs. Mov earns her living by making baskets for selling, but with this business, she cannot earn enough money to support her family. Thus, she would like to ask for a loan to buy beef and balut eggs for selling. With her new business, she hopes to increase her income to help support her family.

loans.use: To buy beef and balut eggs for selling.

loans.name: Uy's Group

texts.en:
This village bank loA. consists of 16 members. Mr. Uy is the village bank president. He was selected to be the village bank president by the other members. Each member of this group will use their money to support their different needs.

Mr. Uy and his wife are farmers who own a plot of land and a water machine, which they use to grow cucumbers. To support their farming, Mr. Uy would like a loA. to buy fertilizers for growing cucumbers. He will use the rest of the loA. to buy hoses for his water machine.

This couple has worked hard on the farm to support their five children: one is a laborer, one is a construction worker and two are attending the local school, while the youngest one stays at home.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers to grow cucumbers with the remainder of the loan for hoses for his water machine.

loans.name: Hean

texts.en: Hean C., 52, is married and resides in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. C. and her husband are farmers that earn an income of about USD 5 per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 58 on food and USD 30 on the other necessary expenses. C. is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to operate a business as motor-taxi driver. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for her husband.

loans.name: Em

texts.en: Em P., 31, is married and resides in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. Chao and her husband are farmers, earning an income of about USD 5 each per day. When available from the farming business, her husband is also a blacksmith. Each month, the family has to spend USD 58 on food and USD 74 on the other necessary expenses. P. is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase pig food and pigs to raise for sale. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy pig food and pigs to raise for sale.

loans.name: Hun's Group

texts.en:
This group loan consists of four members. Mrs. Hun, who was born in 1949, is the group leader. She was selected to be the group leader by the other members. 

Mrs. Hun is a farmer who rents a plot of land that she uses to grow peanuts for a living. She doesn't have enough money to grow her farming business, so she is asking for a loan to cultivate peanuts. Aside from being a farmer, she also sells Khmer noodles for a small income to improve her family's living. 

Mrs. Hun is a widow with three children: two are seamstresses in the garment factories and one is a student.

loans.use: to cultivate peanuts

loans.name: Sieng

texts.en:
Sieng S. O. is a 23-year-old married woman and mother who lives with other family members in her own small family home in Prey Chor commune of Kompong Cham province. She owns a piece of land that she inherited from her grandmother. She grows different kinds of crops on her land such as cabbage and cucumbers which she sells to buyers every two or three months when the plants mature. Her husband helps her to grow these vegetable crops. 

The couple is married and have two schoO.-aged children. The rains have fallen and the land is suitable for production, so Sieng S. O. has taken out a loan to buy vegetable seeds to sow on her existing farmland. She hopes to use the rest of the money to purchase a used motorbike for traveling needs as her old motorbike often breaks down during riding. Sieng S. O. and her husband are shown in the picture.

loans.use: to buy vegetable seeds to sow on her farmland.

loans.name: Creativas 3 Group

texts.en:
Marileyda requires a loan to buy some beauty and cosmetic products. She runs a small beauty salon, in her house, and with the profits she is planning to save.  In the future she wants to move her business to a local area and have the biggest salon 

Marileyda lives in Santo Domingo, in one of the poorest communities surrounding the main city of the Dominican Republic. Marileyda and her group of 5 members are taking out loans for their businesses. This group is named Creativas 3.

This is Marileyda´s third loan with Esperanza International. She has taken a step toward improving her business by investing every loan to increase her sales. She has had her business for over 1 year and a half , after she took her Esperanza first loan. Her most difficult challenge is to improve her business.

She says that her favorite thing is to learn more by working in her beauty salon. Marileyda and her group are thankful for your support!

loans.use: to buy beauty products.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Sok's Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan is made up of 17 people. Mrs. Sok is the village bank president. She was selected to be the village bank president by the other members. 

Mrs. Sok earns her living by selling fruit. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy more fruit to grow her business. 

Mrs. Sok was born in 1970 and is a widow with two children: one is a car driver and one helps in her mother's business.

loans.use: to buy more fruit to grow her business

loans.name: Zumrathon's Group

texts.en:
Zumrathon I. is the leader of this group. She is 50 and married. Her husband earns money by providing car repair services. Together they have raised two daughters and two sons. The daughters are married and live separately from their parents and the sons are engaged in farming. Zumrathon works as a cleaner. She also cultivates raspberries to make additional money. Selling raspberries, she earns an additional 1,000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase three packs of fertilizer.  In the future, she wants to get a good harvest and then celebrate her older son’s wedding.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase poultry birds.

loans.name: Yun's Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan is made up of 14 people. Mrs. Yun is the village bank president. She was selected to be the village bank president by the other members. 

Her husband, Mr. Keo, is a motorbike taxi driver who is able to earn a small income to help support his family. This couple has a child who is seamstress in a garment factory. 

Her husband's income is not enough to support the family. In order to improve the family’s condition, she would like a loan to buy vegetables for selling.

loans.use: to buy vegetables to sell

loans.name: Penh

texts.en:
The woman shown in the picture above, Penh S. P., is a 39-year-old farmer residing in the rural area of Kompong Cham province. She has been planting rice crops which is her annual business. From her farming business, she is able to generate an income of about 2 USD per day. Her husband works as a construction worker and earn approximately $2.50 to share the responsibility with Penh S. P. to cover the needs of the family. 

The couple is blessed with two children who are attending school. Penh S. P. is requesting a loan to support her farming business. She will use the loan to buy a cow to plow the farmland.

loans.use: to buy a cow to plow the farmland.

loans.name: Creciendo Para El Futuro 1, 2 & 3 Group

texts.en:
Adriana is the coordinator of her group Creciendo Para el Futuro 1, 2 & 3, (Growing for the Future). She makes her home here in a simple structure and is working hard to attend the university and become professional. 

Having repaid her previous loan and grown her business, Adriana is excited to be taking her sixth loan with Esperanza. She has had her business for around four years, cooking foods and delivering them to people. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business by buying rice, beans, cooking oil, meat and chairs. She will use the additional profits to save and supply some needs for her only child and home. In the near future, she wants to build her house.

She said that her most difficult challenge is to build a safe and better built house. She enjoys being with her child and working at home.

This Esperanza associate began with us because the loans are for business and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in Samana, a lush rugged peninsula with a nascent tourism industry. This area, like nearly all impoverished areas of the Dominican Republic, suffers from unreliable running water (none of which is potable) and electricity.

loans.use: to buy rice, beans, cooking oil, meat and chairs

loans.name: Suon

texts.en:
Mrs. Suon was born in 1973. She is married to Mr. Phoa who was born in 1972. They have five children. Three of the children are attending the local school and the other two are too young to work.

She and her husband are farmers who own a plot of land that they use to grow rice for their family. Currently, they want to grow rice in the dry season, but they don’t have enough money to grow it. Thus, Mrs. Suon would like to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers and gasoline for cultivating rice. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and gasoline

loans.name: Gulhumor's Group

texts.en:
Gulhumor I. is the treasurer of this group. She is 21 and in order to earn money for her livelihood, she takes orders and sews women's dresses. She started this activity four years ago with an initial investment of 1,000 soms and now she earns 2,000 soms per month. Gulhumor started sewing a long time ago. She sewed dresses for her younger sisters when they were children. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase fabrics and materials that are needed for sewing. In the future, Gulhumor dreams of opening a sewing workshop.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase fabric and materials

loans.name: Esperanza Para Vivir 1 & 2 Group

texts.en:
Bienvenida lives in Santiago, the second biggest city in the Dominican Republic. The economy depends on agricultural industries. Bienvenida and her group of 10 members are taking loans for their businesses. This group is named Esperanza para vivir 1, & 2 (Hope to live).

Bienvenida requires a loan to purchase underwear and accessories. She runs a small business selling in her neighborhood and by walking through different communities. This is Bienvenida´s first loan with Esperanza International. She will take a step toward improving her business by investing this loan to increase her sales. She has had her business for over two years, after she decided to start doing business and identified that underwear sales was the right activity to do.
 
She says that her favorite things are to cook and to rest at her home.  Bienvenida and her group are thankful for your support!

loans.use: to buy underwear and accessories to sell

loans.name: Chebet

texts.en:
Chebet is a farmer in the Kitale area in Western Kenya and has been in the farming business for three years. She engages the services of two farmhands and sells her eggs to the local market. She is married with two children aged 8 and 3. Both are schooling.

Chebet has made a request for a loan amounting to 41,600 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She says she wants to venture into dairy farming to diversify her interests so she'll have some security from the outbreaks of poultry diseases. She says her focus is to own better breeds of dairy cows once the business is up and running.

Chebet concurs with other farmers that animal diseases are their main undoing in business. She appreciates Juhudi Kilimo's empowering mechanism.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Mira's Group

texts.en:
Mira A. is a member of this group. She is 40 and married to a tractor driver. Together they bring up two daughters and two sons. The first son studies at the university and the other children are at school. The family is engaged in agriculture. They cultivate agricultural products and then after getting the harvest, they sell some part of it to make money. In this way, they earn 8500 soms per month. With money received from the loan, Mira wants to purchase 30 liters of fuel and potato seeds. In the future, she wants to provide her children with a good education. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase potato seeds and fuel

loans.name: La Esperanza El Coco 1 & 2 Group

texts.en:
Menenciana lives in the coconut village of Samana. She and her group of 10 members are taking loans for their businesses. This group is named La Esperanza el coco (the hope of coconut) 1 & 2.

Menenciana's family is maD. up of her long-term partner and their two children. She tells us that her most difficult challenge is to reach her goal of having a good business that generates good income.

This group is dedicated to many different businesses like selling clothes, shoes, cosmetics, and a little restaurant. Menenciana is selling clothes. She is very excited to belong to this group and start having a loan for her business and a chance to improve her business.

Menenciana is planning on investing her new loan in the purchase of clothing. She will use her profits to continue investing in her business to improve sales, incorporating more products and saving. She hopes in the not too distant future to have her dream of building her house come true. She also wants to have good health and a more economically stable life.

loans.use: to buy clothing to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy 50 crates of assorted drinks.

loans.name: Alieu

texts.en:
This is 38 year-old Alieu B..  He is married and has 3 children ages 8, 10 and 12 years old.  In 2004, Alieu B. established his general store business.  He began his business because it is a self employment activity.  Working 6 days a week and 10 hours a day, he earns about 450,000 SLL every month from this business. 

He would like a loan in the amount of 4,000,000 SLL.  Alieu B. requires a loan in order to buy more business stock.  He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits by approximately 300,000 SLL.  In the future, Alieu B. plans to educate his children and open another shop.  He is very serious and dedicated.  He wants to be a supplier.  He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: Buy assorted items by the carton such as plastic bags,soap,sugar,sardine etc

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more local food stuff for business

loans.name: San

texts.en:
San S. is a bean juice seller in the rural area of Phnom Pech city. He and his wife always get up early in the morning in order to take part of their bean crop to grind to get fresh bean juice to sell at the marketplace. They can earn around $5 in profit for their juice sales business. 

They have been married for years and are blessed with only one child who lives under their roof. This family has a problem with living conditions as they want to move their house onto a bigger plot of land which they bought previously. This is the reason why San S. would like to request a loan from Kiva.

loans.use: To pay for moving their house onto a bigger plot of land which they bought previously.

loans.name: Manantial De Vida 1 & 3 Group

texts.en:
Alfida is one of the members of the group named Manantial D. vida 1 & 3. They are located in Samana, a city known for its developing tourism and for being a special destination due to eco-tourism with many natural attractions. At the same time, it still has many needs and communities with very few resources and few means of support. Alfida and her group of 9 other members are taking loans for their businesses.

Alfida requires a loan to buy underwear and shoes. She sells them in her house and in other places. She started her business with part of her savings and she has had it for over three years. She will take a step toward improving her business by investing this loan to increase her sales.

Thanks to their loans, Alfida and her group have been able to take a step toward improving their lives, their families’ and their communities’ lives. She thanks you for your help.

One of the members was unable to be in the group picture, but we added her picture into the group, after the rest of the members were photographed.

loans.use: to buy underwear and shoes to resell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase poultry

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy cartons of fish for resale

loans.name: Loeung

texts.en:
Loeung H. is a 59-year-old widow and a local villager living in a medium-sized home with family members in Kompong Tom province. She owns a piece of farmland that she inherited many years ago from her grandparents. She uses this land to grow different kinds of crops at least two times per year. She has been getting great results from growing crops. Most of the income in her family comes from her employed daughters who are sewing workers and can earn a salary monthly. 

Presently, they always pay for a motor taxi to go to their workplace. To reduce traveling costs, Loeung H. would like to request a loan to buy a second motorcycle which will be used by her daughters.

loans.use: to buy a second motorcycle to be used by her daughters.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow and poultry

loans.name: Bav

texts.en:
The woman in the photo is Mrs. Bav I., age 28, who lives in the Province of Kompong Tom in Cambodia, where she earns a living raising pigs. Since 2007, she has run this business and it has provided her with income to attain her standard of living. She is married with three children who still study in school. Her husband is a firewood seller. 

Beside raising pigs, she has also been planting rice which is her annual business. Mrs. Bav I. is seeking a loan to buy a cow which can assist her in farm fields. The cow can also be used for breeding purposes so she can raise its offspring.

loans.use: to buy a cow to assist her in farm fields.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy additional bags of local food.

loans.name: Crimildo Agostinho

texts.pt:
Crimildo Agostinho S. nasceu na cidade Matola, Província de Maputo, sul de Moçambique casado e pai de 1 filha de 2 anos de  idade, ainda nao vai a Escola. Fez 4ª classe não continuou  devido as dificuldades da vida. Vive na casa própria com a sua família e sustenta suas sobrinhas que vivem com ele.

Nunca sai da sua cidade natal, possui um negocio proprio de venda de roupa diversa usada e sapatos ha 4 anos. Não possui nenhum empregado e tem um rendimento mensal de 4.000.00mt por mês que aplica nas despesas de casa e consegue poupar uma parte na sua conta bancaria.

Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de seu amigo que é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu primeiro empréstimo na Hluvuku no valor de 10.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar fardos de roupa usada para aumentar a quantidade da sua mercadoria.

Compromete se a pagar devidamente para poder aceder a outros créditos no futuro. Pretende solicitar novos empréstimos para ampliar o seu negocio e concluir a sua casa.
texts.en:
Crimildo Agostinho S. was born in the city of Matola, Maputo Province in southern Mozambique. He is married and has a two-year-old daughter who does not yet attend school. Crimildo finished fourth grade but did not continue because of life's difficulties. He lives in his own house with his family and also supports his nieces, who live with him.

He has never left his hometown, and for more than four years he has had his own business selling assorted used clothing and shoes. He has no employees and has a monthly income of 4,000 meticais, which he uses for household expenses. He is also able to save some money in his bank account.

Crimildo has never had loans from other banks, and he learned about Hluvuku through a friend who is a customer of this institution. This is his first Hluvuku loan, and he is asking for 10,000 meticais to buy bundles of used clothing so he can increase the amount of merchandise he has.

He promises to make his payments on time so he can take out other loans in the future. He intends to ask for more loans to expand his business and finish his house.

loans.use: to buy bundles of assorted used clothing

loans.name: Mariatu

texts.en: Mariatu is a 43-year-old businesswoman.  She is married and has 4 children and an additional dependent, who lives with her as a result of her mother's death. In 2001, Mariatu established her business selling traveling boxes, DVD laptops and ladies' bags. She began her business to realize her dream of independence. Working 6 days a week and 11 hours a day, she earns about SLL 1,000,000 every month. She would like a loan in the amount of SLL 4,000,000 in order to buy more goods for her business. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately SLL 200,000. She thanks you for supporting her.

loans.use: To buy more clothing for her business.

loans.name: Adelaide Luis

texts.pt:
Adelaide Luis C. nasceu na cidade Maputo, Província de mesmo nome, sul de Moçambique solteira mãe de 2 filhos de 8 e 18 anos idade,  vao a Escola. Fez 7ª classe não continuou  porcausa de casamento prematuro. Vive na casa própria com a sua família e não sustenta mais ninguém para alem de seus filhos.

Nunca sai da sua cidade natal, tem um negocio proprio de venda de produtos de primeira necessidade no quintal da sua casa ha 5 anos. Não possui nenhum empregado e tem um rendimento mensal de 5.000.00mt por mês que aplica nas despesas de casa e consegue poupar uma parte na sua conta bancaria.

Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de sua vizinha que é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu terceiro empréstimo na Hluvuku no valor de 20.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar produtos (cervejas, refrescos,vinho, arroz,farinha e outros) para aumentar a quantidade da sua mercadoria.

Compromete se a pagar devidamente para poder aceder a outros créditos no futuro. Pretende solicitar novos empréstimos para ampliar a sua banca.
texts.en:
Adelaide Luis C. was born in the city of Maputo, Maputo Province in southern Mozambique. She is single and has two children, ages 8 and 18, who go to school. Adelaide finished seventh grade but did not continue because of her early marriage. She lives in her own house with her family and does not support anyone other than her children.

She has never left her hometown. For more than five years Adelaide has had her own business selling staple goods in the yard of her house. She has no employees and has a monthly income of 5,000 meticais, which she uses for household expenses. She is also able to save some money in her bank account.

She has never had loans with other banks, and she learned about Hluvuku through her neighbor, who is a customer at this institution. This is Adelaide's third Hluvuku loan. She is asking for 20,000 meticais to buy products (beer, soft drinks, wine, rice, flour and other items) to increase the amount of merchandise she has.

She promises to make her payments on time so she can take out more loans in the future. She intends to ask for more loans to expand her sales stand.

loans.use: to buy products (beer, soft drinks, wine, rice, flour, etc.)

loans.name: 6 Tân Nam - Nam Ngạn Group

texts.en:
"Trường Lê Thị (41) is a 60-year-old woman living in the town of Thanh Hóa. Trường is the group leader of a 4-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 09.1.6 Nam Ngạn (6 Tân Nam   Nam Ngạn).

Trường is widowed and has 3 adult -aged children. She operates a family member's food stall, selling a variety of food products in the local community. Trường has been engaged in this business for over 2 years and earns approximately 2,000,000 VND a month from it.

In 2011, Trường joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Trường is requesting a loan of 4,248,000 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to purchase additional inventory and to increase working capital. This will be her first loan. Trường plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About the other borrowers in the group:

1.  H. Thị Cam (42) is a 51-year-old woman who is requesting a 4,248,000 VND loan to support her specialized retail store.

2.  Lê Thị Tuấn (43) is a 51-year-old woman who is requesting a 4,248,000 VND loan to support her specialized retail store.

3.  N. Thị Kha (44) is a 21-year-old woman who is requesting a 4,248,000 VND loan to support her specialized retail store.

About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Trường Lê Thị (41) là 60 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hóa.  Trường là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 4 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 09.1.6 Nam Ngạn (6 Tân Nam  Nam Ngạn).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ bán các loại thực phẩm khác nhau trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Trường thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 2 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Trường kiếm được khoảng 2,000,000 VND.  Vào 2011, Trường đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Trường đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.    Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 4,248,000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 1st khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  H. Thị Cam (42) là 51 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4,248,000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hiệu bán lẻ chuyên dụng.


2.  Lê Thị Tuấn (43) là 51 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4,248,000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hiệu bán lẻ chuyên dụng.


3.  N. Thị Kha (44) là 21 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4,248,000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hiệu bán lẻ chuyên dụng.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory.

loans.name: Soeurn

texts.en: Soeurn S., age 25, is a building worker and he is able to earn a daily income of around 4 USD to help support his family. He has a life partner in his wife who works a garment worker and has a formal salary. The couple is blessed with a young child who is not yet enrolled in school. Soeurn S. will be using the loan to buy jewelry as an inheritance for his kid as well as selling it out whenever he needs an immediate cash for starting up a new business.

loans.use: to buy jewelry

loans.name: 4 Tiền Phong   Nam Ngạn Group

texts.en:
"Thủy N. Thị (15) is a 43-year-old woman living in the town of Thanh Hóa. Thủy is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 4 Nam Ngạn (4 Tiền Phong - Nam Ngạn).

Thủy is married and has 2 school-aged children. She owns and operates a tailoring business, providing general alteration and tailoring services to local community members. Thủy has been engaged in this business for over 3 years and earns approximately 1,800,000 VND a month from it.

In 2011, Thủy joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Thủy is requesting a loan of 4,248,000 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to purchase additional fabric and materials. This will be her 1st loan from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Thủy plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About the other borrowers in the group:

1.  Vũ Thị Thúy (16) is a 46-year-old woman who is requesting a 4,248,000 VND loan to support her business making and selling food.

2.  N. Thị Hải (17) is a 41-year-old woman who is requesting a 4,248,000 VND loan to support her tailoring business.

3.  N. Thị Phương (18) is a 30-year-old woman who is requesting a 4,248,000 VND loan to support her business running a food stall.

4.  N. Thị Thu (19) is a 45-year-old woman who is requesting a 4,248,000 VND loan to support her business running a food stall.

5.  N. Thị Hường (20) is a 41-year-old woman who is requesting a 4,248,000 VND loan to support her business running a food stall.

About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Thủy N. Thị (15) là 43 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hóa.  Thủy là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 6 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 4 Nam Ngạn (4 Tiền Phong  Nam Ngạn).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ cung cấp các dịch vụ may vá quần áo thông thường cho người dân trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Thủy thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 3 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Thủy kiếm được khoảng 1,800,000 VND.  Vào 2011, Thủy đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Thủy đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.    Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 4,248,000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 1st khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  Vũ Thị Thúy (16) là 46 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4,248,000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.


2.  N. Thị Hải (17) là 41 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4,248,000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh may mặc.


3.  N. Thị Phương (18) là 30 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4,248,000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm.


4.  N. Thị Thu (19) là 45 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4,248,000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm.


5.  N. Thị Hường (20) là 41 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4,248,000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: to purchase additional fabric and materials.

loans.name: El Futuro Del Mañana Group

texts.es: La Sra. Esther es separada  y tiene 3 hijos en edad escolar, Esther  es integrante de la alcancía comunal “ El futuro del Mañana” grupo conformado por 7 socios que se dedican a actividades de comercio, Esther  se dedica a la venta  de pollos y aves  desde hace 3 años este negocio surge a raíz de su divorcio, ya que ella necesitaba mejores ingresos económicos para mantener a sus hijos y es así que  gracias  a su esfuerzo y dedicación a logrado brindarles una mejor calidad de vida , tiene  su local propio y sus  hijos hoy en día  tienen una buena educación. Esther nos cuenta que desea seguir creciendo como empresaria y comprarse otro terreno. El préstamo que  se le otorgo fue para comprar mercadería  para implementar su negocio. Sabemos que Esther   cumplirá sus metas con mucho trabajo y esfuerzo y que los préstamos de Edaprospo la ayudaran.
texts.en:
Esther is separated, and has three school age children.  She is a member of the “El Futuro del Mañana” [The Future of Tomorrow] communal bank, made up of seven members dedicated to business activities.  

Esther is dedicated to chicken and bird sales.  This business arose three years ago because of her divorce, since she needed a better income to support her children.  This is how, thanks to her efforts and dedication, she succeeded in providing them a better quality of life.  

Today, she has her own locale and her children have a good education.  Esther tells us that she would like to continue growing as a businesswoman and buy her own land.  The loan that she was given was for the purchase of merchandise to begin her business.  With a lot of hard work and effort, we know that Esther will fulfill her goals, and that the loans from Edaprospo will help.

loans.use: purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Sara Francisco

texts.pt:
Sara Francisco U. nasceu no Distrito de Magude, Província de Maputo, sul de Moçambique casada mãe de 3 filhos de idades entre 20 a 26 anos de idade, destes 2 vaõ a Escola. Fez somente 4ª classe não continuou devido a dificuldades financeiras pelos pais. Vive na casa própria com a sua família e naõ sustenta mais ninguem.

Saiu de Magude para Boane devido a transferência do marido, possui um negocio proprio de venda de produtos de primeira necessidade ha mais de 8 anos. Naõ tem empregado e consegue um rendimento de cerca de 900.00mt, por mês que aplica nas despesas de casa e a vezes consegue poupar algum na sua conta bancaria.

Nunca teve empréstimo em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de uma mobilização.Este é o seu terceiro empréstimo na Hluvuku no valor de 9.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar mercadoria (sumo, Feijão, caldos, cebola  e outros) para aumentar a quantidade da sua mercadoria. Os emprestimos anteriores foram de 3.500.00mt e 3.000.00mt ambos e foram para o comercio.

Compromete se a pagar devidamente para poder aceder a outros créditos no futuro. Pretende solicitar novos empréstimos para concluir a construção de dependencias e da sua loja.
texts.en:
Sara Francisco U. was born in Magude District, Maputo Province in southern Mozambique. She is married and has three children between 20 and 26 years old; two of the children go to school. Sara only finished fourth grade and did not continue because her parents could not afford it. She lives in her own house with her family and does not support anyone else.

She left Magude to move to Boane when her husband was transferred. For more than eight years she has had her own business selling staple goods. She has no employees and earns an income of about 900 meticais per month which she uses for household expenses. Sometimes she is able to save some money in her bank account.

Sara has never had loans from other banks. She learned about Hluvuku through an enrollment effort. This is Sara's third Hluvuku loan, and she is asking for 9,000 meticais to buy merchandise (juice, beans, broths, onions and other items) to increase the amount of merchandise she has. The previous loans were for 3,500 meticais and 3,000 meticais, and both were for the business.

She promises to make her payments on time so she can take out more loans in the future. She intends to ask for more loans to finish building some bedrooms and building her shop.

loans.use: to buy merchandise (juice, beans, broths, onions, etc.)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a pump.

loans.name: Gulkan's Group

texts.en:
Gulkan M. is the leader of this group. She is 51 and, unfortunately, she is a widow.  Gulkan has raised seven children: five daughters and two sons. Most of her children are married and employed. In order to earn money, Gulkan breeds cattle. She started this activity ten years ago with an initial investment of 15,000 KGS. With the financial help of her children, Gulkan recently bought a new house. She applied for a loan because she needs money to start repairing the house and purchase curtains to improve her living conditions.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to repair her house.

loans.name: Chil's Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of 16 members. Mrs. Chil, a married woman who was born in 1980, is the village bank president; she was selected by the other members. 

Her husband, Mr. Koy, was born in 1978 and is a farmer who owns a plot of land and an agri-machine to grow rice for a living. He alS. earns a living by renting the agri-machine to villagers. This couple has three children: two are attending the local schoO. and the youngest one is a year old. 

Mrs. Chil's husband's farming does not earn enough money to support the family. In order to improve her family’s condition, she would like a loan to buy piglets for breeding.

loans.use: to buy piglets for breeding

loans.name: Angelina Maivasse

texts.pt:
Angelina Maivasse B. nasceu no Distrito de Boane, Província de Maputo, sul de Moçambique solteira mãe de 1 filho de 8 anos idade,  vai a Escola. Fez 10ª classe não continuou devido a falta de condicoes financeiras. Vive na casa própria com a sua família e não sustenta mais ninguém para alem de seu filho.

Nunca sai da sua cidade natal, tem um negocio proprio de venda de frangos ha mais de 10 anos. Não possui nenhum empregado e tem um rendimento mensal de 4.000.00mt por mês que aplica nas despesas de casa e consegue poupar uma parte na sua conta bancaria.

Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de sua vizinha que é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu Quinto empréstimo na Hluvuku no valor de 20.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construcao (cimentos, chapas, barrotes e outros) para continuidade da sua obra.

Compromete se a pagar devidamente para poder aceder a outros créditos no futuro. Pretende solicitar novos empréstimos para ampliar a sua banca e concluir a sua casa.
texts.en:
Angelina Maivasse B. was born in Boane District, Maputo Province, in the south of Mozambique. She is a single mother of an 8-year-old son who attends school. She completed 10th grade but didn't continue attending school due to her financial circumstances. 

She lives in her own house with her family and doesn't support anyone besides her son. She's never left her native city, and she has had her own business selling chickens for over ten years. She does not have employees and has monthly earnings of 4,000 meticais. She uses these for household expenses, while managing to save a portion in her bank account. 

She has never taken loans from other banks, and learned of Hluvuku through her neighbor who is a client of this institution. This is her fifth loan with Hluvuku. The amount of the loan is 20,000 meticais, which she plans to use to purchase construction materials (cement, sheet metal, beams, and other items) to continue her construction project. She is committed to repaying on time in order to obtain other loans in the future. She plans to request new loans to expand her sales stand.

loans.use: to purchase construction materials (cement, sheet metal, beams, and other items).

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase products (soft drinks, beer, sugar, juice, soup, and other items).

loans.name: Chhit

texts.en:
Chhit S. is a Khmer cake seller in and around a busy market in Battambang province. The cake is made from rice which is cooked in bamboo tubes. She typically makes around $3 in profit each day to ensure that her family has a comfortable life. She has been married for many years to Pout Hin, 48, a construction worker, and they have five children; three are single, and two are married. 

Beside this work, she has also been planting rice crops. Presently, Chhit S. is not yet planting crops on her farmland as she doesn’t have enough funds to do. She hopes to use this Kiva loan to purchase seed and fertilizer for growing crops.

loans.use: to purchase seed and fertilizer for growing crops.

loans.name: 5 Tiền Phong  Nam Ngạn Group

texts.en:
Hoa Ngô Thị (21) is a 40-year-old woman living in the town of Thanh Hóa. Hoa is the leader of a four-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 5 Tiền Phong  Nam Ngan (12.1.5 Nam Ngạn).

Hoa is married and has two school-aged children. To making a living, Hoa owns and operates a hairdressing and beauty salon. Hoa has been engaged in this business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000,000 VND a month.
