In 2011, Hoa joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Hoa is requesting her first loan from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. She is requesting 4,248,000 VND, which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide her beauty salon service. Hoa plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About the other borrowers in the group:
1. P. Thị T. Hà (22) is a 36-year-old woman who is requesting a 4,248,000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector running a food stall.

2. K. Thị Thuận (23) is a 30-year-old woman who is requesting a 4,248,000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector running a food stall.

3. N. Thị Yến (24) is a 34-year-old woman who is requesting a 4,248,000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector running a food stall.

About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:
The mission of Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Hoa Ngô Thị (21) là 40 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hóa.  Hoa là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 4 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 5 Tiền Phong Nam Ngan (5  Nam Ngạn).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ cung cấp các dịch vụ làm tóc & làm đẹp cho người dân trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Hoa thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 5 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Hoa kiếm được khoảng 3,000,000 VND.  Vào 2011, Hoa đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Hoa đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.    Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 4,248,000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 1st khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  P. Thị T. Hà (22) là 36 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4,248,000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm.


2.  K. Thị Thuận (23) là 30 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4,248,000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm.


3.  N. Thị Yến (24) là 34 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4,248,000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: to purchase materials needed for her beauty salon business.

loans.name: Delfina Manhica

texts.pt:
Delfina Manhiça L. nasceu no Distrito de Boane, Província de Maputo, sul de Moçambique Viuva e maê de 8 filhos os 2 mais novos ainda vao a Escolade. Fez somente 4ª classe nao continuou por falta de condições financeiras. Vive na casa própria com seus filhos e naõ sustenta ninguem para além de seus filhos.

Nunca saiu da sua terra natal, tem uma terra onde pratica agricultura ha mais de 20 anos plantandoculturas para comercialização e consumo. Possui 2 empregados que lhe auxiliam na preparação da terra e consegue um rendimento de cerca de 8.5.000.00mt por mês e 3.200.00mt de proveniente da renda da casa que aplica nas despasas de casa e consegue poupar uma parte na sua conta bancaria.

Ja teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de vizinhos que são clientes desta instituição. Este é o seu quinto empréstimo na Hluvuku no valor de 20.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção ( blocos, cimento, ferro, barrotes e outros) para continuar com a construcao da sua casa.

Compromete se a pagar devidamente para poder aceder a outros créditos no futuro, pretende solicitar novos empréstimos para aplicar no projecto de criação de gado bovino.
texts.en:
Delfina Manhiça L. was born in Boane District, in Maputo Province, in the south of Mozambique. She is the mother of 8 children, and the two youngest are still attending school. She only completed 4th grade and didn't continue in school due to financial circumstances. She lives in her own home with her children, and doesn't support anyone besides her children.

She has never left her native region. She has land where she has been farming for over 20 years, planting crops for sales and for consumption. She has two employees who help her in preparing the land. She has monthly earnings of around 85,000 meticais and 3,200 meticais in earnings from rent. She uses these earnings for household expenses and manages to save a portion in her bank account. 

She has taken loans from other banks in the past. She learned of Hluvuku through neighbors who are clients of this institution. This is her fifth loans with Hluvuku. The loan is for 20,000 meticais, and she plans to use it to purchase construction materials (bricks, cement, iron, beams, and other items) to continue the construction of her home.

She is committed to repaying on schedule to be able to access other loans in the future. She plans to request new loans for cattle raising.

loans.use: to purchase construction materials (bricks, cement, iron, beams, and other items).

loans.name: Shalom: Dios Con Nosotros Group

texts.es: La Sra. Blanca es conviviente  y tiene 1 hija D. un año D. edad,Blanca es integrante D. la alcancía comunal “SHALOM:DIOS CON NOSOTROS” grupo conformado por 7 socios que se dedican a actividades D. comercio, blanca  tiene su propia librería donD. venD. lápiz, cuadernos  y útiles D. escritorio, saca copias y impresiones desD. hace 7 años este negocio surge a raíz D. que ella quería pagar sus estudios D. enfermería y es así que  gracias  a su esfuerzo y dedicación se compro su terreno, una fotocopiadora y una computadora y a su vez  ha  logrado terminar su carrera D. enfermera, y pueD.  brindarles una mejor calidad D. vida a su hija. El préstamo que  se le otorgo fue para comprar mercadería  para implementar su negocio. Sabemos que Blanca  cumplirá sus metas con mucho trabajo y esfuerzo y que los préstamos D. Edaprospo la ayudaran.
texts.en:
Blanca lives with her partner and has a one year old daughter.  Blanca is a member of the “Shalom: Dios Con Nosotros” [Shalom: God With Us] communal bank, maD. up of seven members dedicated to trading activities.  Blanca has her own bookstore where she sells pencils, notebooks and other office supplies, and makes copies and prints.  

This business arose seven years ago because Blanca wanted to pay for her nursing studies.  Thanks to her efforts and her dedication, she bought land, a photo copier and a computer.  In the meantime, she succeeded in completing her nursing career and can now proviD. a better quality of life to her daughter.

The loan Blanca was given was for the purchase of merchandise to begin her business.  With much work and effort, we know that Blanca will fulfill her goals, and that the loans from Edaprospo will help her.

loans.use: purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Ainura's Group

texts.en:
Ainura A. is the treasurer of this group. She is 38 and married. Her husband went to work in Russia to make money. Ainura takes care of four daughters. The first daughter works in Kazakhstan, the second helps her mom with housework and the other two study at school. 

In order to earn money to meet family needs, Ainura cultivates cotton and then sells it on the market. She has been cultivating cotton for 15 years. The family is also engaged in cattle breeding. Ainura applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase wood in order to finish the construction of a stable. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: people (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase wood for a stable.

loans.name: Mov's Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of 14 members. Mrs. Mov T. was selected by the group members to be the village bank president. 

Mrs. Mov is 53 years old, married, and has three children, two of whom are seamstresses and one of whom attends school.  She and her husband are farmers who own a plot of land where they grow rice. She is requesting a loan, which she will use to grow rice in the dry season. They also earn additional income by growing mushrooms and morning glory.

loans.use: to grow rice

loans.name: Bayarjargal

texts.en:
Bayarjargal B. is a 37-year-old divorcee. She lives with her only daughter, Munkhjargal, 16, in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her daughter attends a secondary school. 

Bayarjargal is a hardworking woman with a strong desire to raise a healthy daughter and to give her a proper education. Seven years ago she bought a minivan and obtained a license to carry passengers on one of the remote bus lanes. She hired a driver and she works as a conductor. During the past seven years she has gained a lot of experience and her business is running smoothly. 

Each year she has to pass the safety test for her minivan and every two to three years she has to renew the car. Now it is time for the test. Therefore, she is planning to do a proper annual service to her minivan, servicing the engine, replacing seats and doing some body work. The loan she is requesting will be used to pay for spare parts and for the service to her minivan, including engine and body work.

loans.use: To pay for spare parts and to repair her minivan to meet the transportation authorities' requirements.

loans.name: Fernando Lourenco

texts.pt:
Fernando Lorenço S. nasceu na cidade de Maputo, Província de Maputo, sul de Moçambique casado e pai de 3 filhos todos vaõ a Escola. Fez 9ª classe nao continuou por falta de condições financeiras. Vive na casa própria com a sua familia e sustenta a maê enviando dinheiro.

Nunca saiu da sua terra natal, faz prestação de serviços de canalização de agua e consegue um rendimento de cerca de 3.000.00mt, a 4.000.00mt por mês que aplica nas despasas de casa e consegue poupar uma parte na sua conta bancaria.

Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de seu cunhado que é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu primeiro empréstimo na Hluvuku no valor de 20.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção ( areia, pedra, blocos, cimento, ferro e outros) para continuar com a construcao da sua casa.

Compromete se a pagar devidamente para poder aceder a outros créditos no futuro, pretende solicitar novos empréstimos para construir um armazem de venda de material de construçaõ.
texts.en:
Fernando Lorenço S. was born in Maputo City, Maputo Province in southern Mozambique. He is married and has three children who all go to school.  Fernando finished ninth grade but did not continue because of financial problems. He lives in his own house with his family and supports his mother by sending her money.

He has never left his hometown. Fernando installs plumbing for running water and earns about 3,000 to 4,000 meticais per month. He uses the money for household expenses and saves some in his bank account.

He has never had loans from other banks, and he learned about Hluvuku through his brother-in-law, who is a customer of this institution. This is Fernando's first Hluvuku loan. He is asking for 20,000 meticais to buy construction materials (sand, stone, blocks, cement, iron and other items) to continue construction on his house.

He promises to make his payments on time so he can take out other loans in the future. He intends to ask for more loans to build a warehouse for selling construction materials.

loans.use: to buy construction materials (sand, stone, blocks, cement, iron, etc.)

loans.name: Nargiza's Group

texts.en:
Nargiza S. is the leader of this group. She is 42 and married. Her husband is engaged in cattle breeding. Together they are bringing up a son and two daughters. All the children study at school. 

The family cultivates agricultural products to make a living. With money gained from selling the harvest, Nargiza bought a cow and started to sell milk. In this way she earns 6,000 KGS per month. 

She hopes to obtain the loan because she needs money to purchase more farm animals in order to resell them at the higher price after fattening. In the future, Nargiza wants to provide her children a good education.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: people (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase farm animals.

loans.name: Sum's Group

texts.en:
There are 14 people in this village bank loan group. Mrs. Sum was selected by the members to be the village bank president. 

Mrs. Sum is 39 years old, widowed, and has two children, both of whom attend schoO. and help with the farm.  She is a farmer who owns a plot of land, where she grows rice. She also earns additional income by cultivating mushrooms. She is requesting a loan, which she will use to buy fertilizers for growing rice and to cultivate mushrooms.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers for growing rice.

loans.name: Orlando Carlos

texts.pt:
Orlando Carlos L. nasceu na cidade de Maputo, Província de Maputo, sul de Moçambique casado e pai de 2 filhos o mais velho vai a Escola. Fez 10ª classe nao continuou por falta de condições financeiras. Vive na casa cedida pelos pais com a sua familia e naõ sustenta mais ninguem.

Nunca saiu da sua terra natal, faz prestação de serviços de canalização de agua e consegue um rendimento de cerca de 3.000.00mt, a 4.000.00mt por mês que aplica nas despasas de casa e consegue poupar uma parte na sua conta bancaria.

Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de seu cunhado que é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu primeiro empréstimo na Hluvuku no valor de 20.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar produtos ( cerveja, refrescos e outras bebidas) para aumentar a quantidade da sua mercadoria.

Compromete se a pagar devidamente para poder aceder a outros créditos no futuro, pretende solicitar novos empréstimos para construir uma mercearia e adquirir um meio de transporte para facilitar o seu trabalho.
texts.en:
Orlando Carlos L. was born in the city of Maputo, Maputo Province, in southern Mozambique. He is married and the father of two children, with the oldest attending school. He completed 10th grade, but didn't continue in school due to his financial circumstances. 

He lives with his family in a home given to him by his parents, and doesn't support anyone else. He has never left his native region. He provides plumbing services and has monthly earnings of around 3,000 to 4,000 meticais. He uses these for household expenses and manages to save a portion in his bank account. 

He has never taken loans from other banks, and learned of Hluvuku through his brother-in-law, who is a client of this institution. This is his first loan with Hluvuku and is for 20,000 meticais. He plans to use the loan to purchase products (beer, soft drinks, and other drinks) to increase his inventory level. He is committed to repaying on schedule to be able to access other loans in the future. He plans to request new loans to build a grocery store and to obtain a vehicle to facilitate his work.

loans.use: to purchase products (beer, soft drinks, and other drinks).

loans.name: Try

texts.en:
Try S., 43, is married with two young children living at home in the Kompong Cham province. 

She is a farmer who works for less than US $1 each day and her husband raises pigs. Her husband, Sork Pov, typically makes about US $2 each day as a pig farmer. 

Try S. would like a loan of US $1,200 to purchase more pigs to breed and also to purchase feed for the pigs. S.'s husband appears in the photograph because S. is not available.

loans.use: to buy pigs to breed and also to purchase feed for the pigs.

loans.name: Mahutondji De Calavi Group

texts.fr: MAHUTONDJI DE CALAVI est un groupe de trois personnes, dont les membres se connaissent dans l'exercice de leurs activité. La représentante du groupe, Lucienne Mahudjro (dont le doigt est levé sur la photo), est mariée à Apollinaire un couturier. Le couple a trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Il y a près de huit ans que Lucienne Mahudjro vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari à Abomey Calavi, une ville du  Bénin. Le couple assure ensemble les diverses charges familiales. Lucienne Mahudjro vend depuis quinze ans déjà, des condiments de sauce, des épices et des conserves à Calavi. Cette activité lui génère des revenus l'aidant à s'impliquer dans l'éducation et les autres charges de ses enfants. Lucienne Mahudjro s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est la première fois que Lucienne Mahudjro sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un crédit en vue d'accroître son stock de produits et de mieux satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle.
texts.en: "Mahutondji de Calavi" is a group consisting of three people who know each other from running their businesses. The group representative, Lucienne Mahudjro (whose finger is raised in the photo), is married to Apollinaire, a dressmaker. The couple have three children, all of whom are in school. For close to eight years, Lucienne has lived together with her husband and children in Abomey Calavi, a city in Benin. The couple deal with the various family expenses together. For fifteen years, Lucienne Mahudjro has been selling sauce condiments, spices, and canned goods in Calavi. This business provides her with an income that helps her pay for her children's education and other costs. Lucienne Mahudjro gets her supplies at Dantokpa, the international market in Benin. This is the first time she is seeking a loan with ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners), with the goal of increasing her stocks of merchandise and better satisfying the demands of her clientele.

loans.use: to buy spices, canned goods, and sauce condiments.

loans.name: Sos

texts.en: Sos M., 38, is a widow who lives with two of her children in Kampong Cham province. She purchases and resells motorbikes. She also grows yams and sells them at the local market. On average, she is able to make about US $5 of profit each day. To earn more money, she is asking for a loan of US $300 to purchase yams in bulk for resale.

loans.use: to buy yams in bulk for resale.

loans.name: Ray

texts.en: Mrs. Ray P. is 32 years old and a married woman who has been living the province of Siem Reap. To earn a living, Ray P. and her husband sell some grocery items, both retail and wholesale, at the local market. They have several years of experience in this sector and earn approximately $6 per day. They have been marred for several years and have six young children who attend school. She will use her loan to purchase additional grocery inventory. This loan will really increase her net income so she can use this cash to support her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional grocery inventory.

loans.name: Lidia Pedro

texts.pt:
Lidia Pedro M. nasceu no Distrito de Chokwe, Província de Gaza, sul de Moçambique casada e maê de 5 filhos de idades entre 10 a 27 anos de todos vão a Escola. Fez 6ª classe nao continuou por falta de condições financeiras. Vive na casa propria com a sua familia e naõ sustenta mais ninguem.

Saiu de Gaza para Boane ainda jovem, procurando aumentar a sua formação academica. Tem um negocio proprio de venda de produtos de primeira necessidade ha mais de 15 anos. Não possui nenhum empregado e tem um rendimento de cerca de 3.000.00mt, a 4.000.00mt por mês que aplica nas despasas de casa e consegue poupar uma parte na sua conta bancaria.

Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de amigo que é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu segundo empréstimo na Hluvuku no valor de 20.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção ( areia, cimento, barrotes e outros) para iniciar a sua obra de construção da sua residência. O emprestimo anterior foi de 11.000.00mt aplicado no comercio.

Compromete se a pagar devidamente para poder aceder a outros créditos no futuro, pretende solicitar novos empréstimos para continuar com a sua obra e aumentar a mercadoria.
texts.en:
Lidia Pedro M. was born in Chokwe District, Gaza Province, in southern Mozambique. She is married and the mother of 5 children, between 10 and 27 years of age. All attend school. She completed 6th grade and didn't continue her schooling due to her financial circumstances. She lives in her own home with her family and doesn't support anyone else.

She left Gaza Province for Boane when she was still young, seeking to increase her schooling. She has had her own business selling basic goods for over 15 years. She doesn't have any employees, and has monthly earnings of around 3000 to 4000 meticais, which she uses for household expenses while managing to save a portion in her bank account.

She has never taken loans from other banks, and learned of Hluvuku through a friend who is a client of the institution. This is her second loan with Hluvuku. The loan is for 20,000 meticais and she plans to purchase construction materials (sand, cement, beams, and other items) to start construction of her residence. The previous loan was for 11,000 meticais and was used for her business.

She is committed to repaying on schedule to be able to access future loans. She plans to request new loans to continue with her construction and to increase her inventory.

loans.use: to purchase construction material (sand, cement, beams, and others).

loans.name: Phoung's Group

texts.en:
Thirteen people make up this village bank loan. Mrs. Phuong was selected as the village bank president by the other members. 

Mrs. Phuong is a farmer who owns a 1-hectare plot of land that she uses to grow rice. She also earns a living by cultivating mushrooms. 

Her husband, Mr. Keom, is a construction foreman who is able to earn a small income to support his family. This couple has four children. Three are attending the local school and the youngest one is 3 years old.

Mrs. Phuong wants to improve her family’s condition, so she is requesting a loan to buy piglets for breeding.

loans.use: To buy piglets for breeding.

loans.name: Sabinahon's Group

texts.en:
Sabinahon A. is the leader of this group. She is 54 and, unfortunately, she is a widow. She has a daughter of 20 years old, who is a babysitter, and a son of 22 years old, who works in construction. When Sabinahon was young, her mom taught her how to sew clothes and blankets. Sabinahon now takes orders and sews Kyrgyz national clothing and blankets. With money gained from her business, she built a kiosk near her house and sells convenience goods there. Sabinahon hopes to obtain this loan, which she will use to purchase fabric and materials for sewing and convenience goods for her kiosk. In the future, she wants to see her daughter get married.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase fabric and materials.

loans.name: Lach

texts.en:
Lach P. is 43 years old and blessed with seven single children who still live with him. He is married to Toun Hor, who is 44 years old, and lives in the Siem Reap province. Lach runs a motor taxi in and around his community, earning about 5 USD daily. His wife is a domestic porter who earns an average of 3 USD a day. This money is used to meet the family’s expenses. 

Lach’s current motorbike often breaks down while he is using it. Therefore, he requesting a loan of 400 USD to buy a new motor and repair his motorcycle taxi.

loans.use: to buy a new motor and repair his motorcycle

loans.name: Baraka Alanine Group

texts.fr: Nkubonage Z. est entrepreneur, conseillère du groupe d’affaire « Baraka Alanine »,  âgée de 39 ans, mariée, mère de 8 enfants. Son mari est un chauffeur mécanicien indépendant. La cliente Nkubonage Z. est vendeuse des articles divers au marché communal de Katindo -Alanine.  Il ya 4 ans qu’elle est exerce cette activité. Elle démarra son business avec  250$ reçu de son mari. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner avec  les habits à revendre (10 boubous, 50 bodys, 70 jupes, 30 écharpes foulards). En plus, elle ambitionne agrandir son entreprise, scolariser ses enfants jusqu’au niveau de BAC +5.  La cliente Nkubonage Z.  remercie Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres exclus de banque classique. Il sied de signaler que le groupe d’affaire «  Baraka Alanine » est majoritairement féminins.
texts.en: Nkubonage Z. is an entrepreneur, and an advisor to the "Baraka Alanine" group, composed primarily of women . She is 39 years old, and a married mother of eight. Her husband is a self-employed driver/mechanic.  Nkubonage Z. sells various items of clothing at the Katindo-Alanine town market.   She has worked in this field for the past four years, having started out with $250 from her husband. This new loan will enable her to stock up on dresses to sell (10 boubous - African robes, 50 "bodys", 70 skirts, and 30 headscarves). Furthermore, she is seeking to grow her business and to see to her children's education up to BAC+5 (post-secondary education).  Nkubonage Z.  would like to thank Hekima for helping those excluded from ordinary banking activities.

loans.use: to purchase 10 boubous (African robes), 50 "bodys", 70 skirts, and 30 headscarves

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Suon

texts.en: Mrs. Suon, who was born in 1974, is a widow with 5-year-old twins who are not in school yet. Mrs. Suon is a farmer who owns a plot of land where she cultivates rice for a living. She wants to cultivate rice in the dry season, but she doesn’t have enough money to do so. Therefore, she would like to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers, gasoline, and pesticides to support her crop. Mrs. Suon also works as a farming laborer in the local village.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers, gasoline, and pesticides to support her crop.

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les sept femmes du groupe Benkadi sont mariées majoritairement dans des familles monogames avec en moyenne 32 ans et 5 enfants par femme. Elles habitent toutes dans le quartier Hamdallaye de la ville de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers leurs activités génératrices de revenus au marché Château de Ségou. 
Les membres du groupe font l’achat et la vente de condiments (tablettes de cubes jumbo), pâtes alimentaires, bananes, tissus traditionnels (Dali fini ou Koba), foulards, sacs à main, encens et bois de chauffe. 
Dans le but d’augmenter leur fonds de commerce les membres du groupe ont adhéré à Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 2ème cycle de prêt solidaire.
 Madame Malado   C. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 7 pagnes de tissus traditionnels avec les tisserands installés au grand marché de Ségou.  Elle se ravitaille en gros et revend en détail, au comptant et à crédit, à domicile, en ambulant et au marché Château à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Madame Malado  C. espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 30 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et prendre en charge les petits besoins du foyer. A l’instar des autres membres du groupe, elle a pour objectif d’augmenter le volume de son activité dans ce partenariat avec Soro Yiriwaso.
texts.en: The seven women of the Benkadi group are 32 years old, married with an average of 5 children each, and mostly live in monogamous families.  They all live in the Hamdallaye quarter of Ségou, the fourth largest administrative region of the Republic of Mali), and met through their business dealings. The group's members buy and sell condiments (Jumbo stock cubes), pasta, bananas, traditional cloths (finished Dali or Koba), headscarves, handbags, incense and firewood. In order to boost their working capital, the members joined Soro Yiriwaso and are on their second microcredit loan cycle. Mrs Malado C. aims to use her loan to buy 7 traditional wax clothes from the fabric suppliers in Ségou's market. She buys wholesale and sells via retail for cash or credit.  She goes from door to door and sells from the Château market to a customer base made up of men and women.  Mrs C. hopes to generate an average monthly profit of 30,000 FCFA which she will reinvest in the business and use to meet her family's everyday needs.  Like the other group members, she wishes to boost her business revenues through this partnership with Soro Yiriwaso.

loans.use: to purchase traditional cloths (finished Dali or Koba)

loans.name: Chheng

texts.en:
Chheng T. is 27 years old and sells items such as cooking ingredients, sweets, and soft drinks in front of her house. Chheng’s retail customers are passers-by as well as nearby neighbors. She has been running her shop for a long time and earns around 4 USD a day. Her husband works in the construction sector and also is a fisherman to earn extra income. The couple has a lovely young child who is attending school. 

Chheng is requesting a loan to buy extra grocery items to sell at her shop. She will also save part of her loan so that her husband may buy fishing tools.

loans.use: to buy grocery items and fishing equipment

loans.name: Peang

texts.en:
Mrs. Peang, born in 1955, is a widow. She sells Chinese noodle soup and pork rice to earn a small income in order to support her family. Additional income comes from one child who is a seamstress in a garment factory. 

In order to increase her income to improve the family’s living conditions, Mrs. Peang would like to ask for a loan to buy more Chinese noodles and supplies for the preparation of Chinese noodle soup and pork rice.

loans.use: to buy more Chinese noodles and supplies for the preparation of Chinese noodle soup and pork rice

loans.name: Elchadaï Group

texts.fr: ELCHADAÏ est un groupe de trois personnes, dont les membres appartiennent à la même Église. La présidente du groupe, Clémence colette  (dont le doigt est levé sur la photo), est née le 12 Mai 1975 dans la commune d’Abomey Calavi. Clémence colette  est mariée à un instituteur du nom de Dénis. Le couple a quatre enfants à charge, tous scolarisés, dont trois sont leurs propres enfants. Il y a près de vingt ans que Clémence colette  vit au quartier Allédjo dans la commune d’Abomey Calavi avec sa famille. Le couple subvient ensemble aux divers besoins du ménage. Clémence colette n’a jamais été à l’école. Pour se prendre en charge et assurer les besoins de ses enfants, Clémence colette  mène comme activité depuis onze ans, la vente d’ustensiles de cuisine (plastiques, bols, bassines, etc.). De façon secondaire, Clémence colette  vend des tissus, ce qui lui permet de diversifier ses sources de revenus. Clémence colette  achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C’est la première fois que Clémence colette  sollicite un crédit auprès de ALIDé, crédit qui permettra certainement à Clémence colette et à son groupe d’accroître leur stock de produits et de mieux répondre aux exigences de leur clientèle.
texts.en: ELCHADAÏ is a three-person group whose members belong to the same church. The group's president, Clémence  Colette A. (whose hand is raised in the photo), was born on May 12, 1975 in the commune of Abomey Calavi. She is married to a schoolteacher named Dénis. The couple has three children of their own and one in their care; all are in school. Clémence  and her family have lived in the Allédjo neighborhood of in Abomey Calavi for nearly 20 years. Together the couple provides for the needs of the household. Clémence never went to school. To support her family and assure the needs of her children, Clémence  has run a business for eleven years, selling kitchen utensils (plastic items, bowls, basins, etc.) As a sideline, she sells fabrics, thereby diversifying her revenue sources. Clémence  buys her supplies in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. This is the first time that Clémence  has requested a loan from ALIDé.  This loan will certainly enable her and her group to increase their stock of products and better meet customer demand.

loans.use: To buy bowls, basins, plastic items and fabric.

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Mariées majoritairement dans des familles monogames avec en moyenne 32 ans et 5 enfants, les huit femmes du groupe Danaya habitent toutes dans le quartier Hamdallaye de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des relations de voisinage et de leurs activités génératrices de revenus au marché Château de Ségou. 
Les membres du groupe font le petit commerce de bananes, jus locaux, bois de chauffe, savon,  pagnes wax, bazins et habits pour enfants. 
Dans le but d’augmenter leur fonds de commerce et de se ravitailler au comptant, les membres du groupe ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 3ème cycle de prêt solidaire.
 Madame Oumou D. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 20 douzaines d’habits pour enfants au grand marché de Bamako en gros. La revente se fait au comptant et à crédit à domicile, en ambulant dans les quartiers et au marché Château, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Madame Oumou D. espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 30 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et prendre en charge les soins de santé des enfants.
texts.en:
The majority of the eight women of the Danaya group are married in monogamous families; on average, they have five children and are 32 years old. They all live in the Hamdallaye neighborhood of Segou (Mali's fourth administrative region). They got to know each other through neighborhood relationships and through their revenues-generating activities on the Chateau de Segou market.
 
The members of the group are active in the retail of bananas, local fruit juices, wood fire, soap, Wax print and bazin cloth, and children's clothing.
In order to increase their stock and to pay cash for new supplies, the group members have decided to collaborate with Soro Yiriwaso. They are on their third cycle of group loan.
 
Mrs. Oumou D. intends to use her loan to purchase twenty dozen of children's outfits on Bamako's great wholesale market. She retails for cash or credit door-to-door, as a traveling salesperson, or on the Chateau market, to a client base comprising both men and women.
 
Mrs. Oumou D. hopes to make a monthly benefit of 30,000 CFA francs with this loan, which will be reinvested in her business and used to provide for her children's healthcare.

loans.use: to purchase children's clothing

loans.name: Haltaji's Group

texts.en:
Haltaji S. is the leader of this group. She is 53 and married to a farmer. Together they have raised two daughters, both married, and a son, who has gone to work in Russia. In order to earn money to meet family needs, Haltaji and her husband cultivate cotton. They started this activity in 1991 with an initial investment of 5,000 KGS. Haltaji has applied for this loan because she needs money to purchase cotton seeds and mineral fertilizers. In the future, Haltaji plans to start livestock breeding and make some repairs to her house.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase cotton seeds and mineral fertilizers.

loans.name: Then

texts.en:
Mrs. Then was born in 1972 and is married to Mr. Lor, who also was born 1972. They have two children who are attending the local school. 

She and her husband are farmers who own a plot of land that they use to grow rice. Aside from farming, they also cultivate mushrooms for their family living. 

Currently, they want to cultivate rice in the dry season, buy they do not have enough money to grow it. Thus, Mrs. Then would like to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers, pesticides, and gasoline for growing rice. 

Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, pesticides, and gasoline for growing rice.

loans.name: Sabougnouman Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre femmes du groupe Sabougnouman sont mariées majoritairement dans des familles monogames avec en moyenne 20 ans et 2 enfants. Elles habitent toutes dans le quartier Hamdallaye de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des relations de parenté et de leurs activités génératrices de revenus au marché Château de Ségou. Les membres du groupe font l’achat et la vente de condiments aliments (piment, poivron, sel iodé,…), bananes, pagnes wax et des habits de la friperie. 
Dans le but d’augmenter leur fonds de commerce les membres du groupe ont intégré Soro Yiriwaso avec qui ils sont à leur 1er cycle de prêt solidaire.
Mademoiselle Awa N., présidente du groupe, est connue et appréciée à Hamdallaye pour sa vente de fruits et légumes dans le marché Château de Ségou. 
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 200kg de banane avec les forains de Koutiala en gros et revend en détail, au comptant et à crédit, à domicile, en ambulant et au marché Château à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. Mademoiselle Awa N. espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 15 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et prendre en charge les petits besoins du foyer.
texts.en:
The four members of the Sabougnouman group are married women who live mostly in monogamous families. They average 20 years of age and two children each. They all live in the district of Hamdallaye, in Ségou (fourth administrative region of Mali). They know one another through ties of kinship and through their income-generating activities at the Château market of Ségou. They buy and sell food condiments (chillies, peppers, iodized salt, etc.), bananas, wax pagnes, and used clothing. 

In order to increase their working capital, they turned to the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution and are currently on their first group loan cycle. 

Miss Awa N. is the president of the group. She is popular in Hamdallaye for her fruit and vegetables sales at the Château market of Ségou. She plans to use her loan to buy 200 kg of bananas from the Koutiala fair vendors. She conducts her sales from her home, door-to-door, and at the Château market, wholesale and at retail, for cash or credit to a clientele composed of both men and women. With this loan, Miss Awa N. hopes to earn an average monthly profit of 15,000 FCFA, which she will use to reinvest in her business and take care of small household expenses.

loans.use: to buy bananas

loans.name: Boldbayar

texts.en:
Boldbayar, 47, is married and lives with his wife and two sons in their own house in the Sansar area of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Boldbayar's wife is an ironer at hospital No 2. His older son, age 24, graduated from college and helps with his father's business. His younger son, age 22, is a circus actor who has gone to Africa to work for a while.

Boldbayar manages a taxi service business with his older son. He started his business in 1995 and it was not as easy as it may seem. It requires great patience and hard work in order to succeed. Boldbayar is one of the lucky men who was able to stabilize his business by providing safe and comfortable rides for his customers. At first, he drove a Sonata and, a few years ago, he managed to replace it with a more advanced vehicle, a Mazda Familia. Boldbayar is planning to continue his business in the future. He is a diligent and open-minded person who says, "I would like to repair my house in order to make it as comfortable as it can be." He is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase new roofing material and some iron boards to repair his house.

loans.use: to purchase new roofing material and iron boards to repair his house.

loans.name: Sem's Group

texts.en:
This group loan consists of four members. Mrs. Sem, who was B. in 1972, was selected to be the group leader by the other members.

Mrs. Sem is a farmer who owns a plot of land that she uses to grow rice for a living. Aside from farming, she also earns a living by breeding pigs. 

Her husband, Mr. Khut, who was B. in 1973, is an iron welder, and he is also a fisherman. This couple has two children. One is a grocery seller and one is a student. 

In order to support her pig breeding, Mrs. Sem would like to ask for a loan to buy pig food.

loans.use: To buy pig food.

loans.name: Duch

texts.en:
Duch R. is 26 years old and lives in Siem Reap province. She is married to Horm Ty, 36, who is a fisherman working in and around the local lakes of their community. For more than five years, Duch has been selling fresh fish in the busy local market. She sells fish that she gets from her husband and also buys fish from her wholesale supplier and other fishermen. 

Duch R. is requesting a loan to buy a used motorcycle so that her husband can run a motor taxi service. With this loan, she hopes to improve her family's standard of living.

loans.use: to buy a used motorcycle so her husband can start a motor taxi service

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy food products and charcoal

loans.name: Bayambatsogt

texts.en:
Bayambatsogt T. is 52 years old and lives with his wife and only daughter in the Sansar area of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They live in a ger, a Mongolian traditional nomadic housing tent in his younger brother's backyard. 

He manages a taxi service and grocery trading businesses with the help of his wife in Ulaanbaatar city. He has been operating the taxi service business for 10 years and has gained much experience. 

His wife is responsible for taking charge of their grocery trading business. At first they used to operate only one grocery store. With years of successful business operation, they managed to open one more store. He attributes their business success to the good location of his store. 

He is a hardworking man who says, "My store locates near to bus stop and because of it, we are able to sell great amount of grocery items. Recently I bought a plot of land in order to build a house for my family." 

He is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more grocery items for his two stores.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery items to sell.

loans.name: Noem

texts.en:
The two people in this picture are Noem S., 25, and her husband, who is 35. They currently live in Siem Reap Province. Noem earns a living by raising pigs behind her house. She raises them to breed and also for slaughter. The couple has four children, all of whom are single. 

In order to earn extra income, Noem is requesting a loan to buy pig feed and to purchase piglets to raise.

loans.use: to buy pig feed and piglets

loans.name: Chim's Group

texts.en:
There are 18 people in this village bank loan group. Mrs. Chim was selected by the group members to be the village bank president. 

Mrs. Chim is 28 years old and single. She is a fisherwoman who is able to earn a small income.  In order to improve her standard of living, she is requesting a loan, which she will use to buy piglets for breeding and pig food.

loans.use: To purchase piglets for breeding and pig food

loans.name: Enkhjargal

texts.en:
Mr.Enkhjargal is a 53-year-old widower who lives with his son, Amartuvshin, 21, in his family house in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His son is a university student. 

Enkhjargal is a pensioner, but he runs a taxi business, earning some money on top of his pension. 

Two years ago Enkhjargal has done some extension to his house, but it is not complete yet. He is planning to complete the building work by laying insulation and bricks to the walls and by replacing the coal-fired heating stove to low-pressure central heating system, which reduces the emission of poisonous smoke into the air and saves on heating cost. Ulaanbaatar city's air quality is at dangerous level, few times exceeding the normal level. It is the one of the biggest problems of Mongolian government at the moment. 

Enkhjargal is going to use his savings to complete the building work, but he needs some extra funding. He has already bought some materials. The loan he is asking will be used to pay for necessary building materials such as cement, bricks, sand, insulation materials and pipes for the internal heating system to complete the building project.

loans.use: To buy building materials such as cement, bricks, sand, insulation and pipes to complete the building project.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is 29 years old and lives in Sinkor. She lives with her boyfriend and they have two children that live with them and are attending school. She was able to go to school and finished 11th grade. 

She started doing business in 2000, carrying cookies and selling them around her neighborhood and around the market. In 2005 she was able to get a place in the market and now has a table where she sells rice, onions, oil, chicken stock powder and other food items. 

She likes being able to save money for herself and her children. Her business is growing and she is getting ready to open a shop. In her new business Alice will keep on selling her current products but also offer dry goods like tissue and soap. 

Alice has requested a loan to purchase tissue, soap, rice and onions. In the future, she wants to build her own house.

loans.use: to purchase tissue, soap, rice and onions

loans.name: Nuon's Group

texts.en:
Eleven people make up this village bank loan. Mrs. Nuon is a village bank president. She was selected to be the village bank president by the other members of the group. 

Mrs. Nuon, who was born in 1969, is married to Mr. Oem, who was born in 1970. They have three children; one sells fruit and the other two attend the local school. Mrs. Nuon's husband is a motorbike taxi driver who is able to earn a small income to help support the family. 

Mrs. Noun earns a living by selling fruit. Since this business is going well, she decided to ask for a loan to buy more fruit to expand her business activities.

loans.use: to buy more fruit to expand her business activities

loans.name: Gunchin-Ish

texts.en:
Gunchin-Ish is 44 years old and lives with her husband and two daughters, aged 21 and 24, in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her family lives in a small house, in the outer ger (traditional Mongolian felt tent) districts. She sells her handmade hats at Narantuul, the largest outdoor market in Mongolia. Gunchin-Ish sews her products with help of her daughters and she sells her handmade hats with help of her husband. 

When they first began their business in 1997, the family made handmade hats at home and sold them at another person’s stall. Now they have about 3,000,000 Mongolian Tugriks (MNT) in working capital at their stall. Gunchin-Ish said “We usually try to make modern hats for our consumers.” 

In order to increase their variety of handmade hats, Gunchin-Ish is requesting a loan of 2,000,000 MNT. In the future, she wants to expand her business with this loan and to be able to build their own hat factory.

loans.use: To purchse more material of handmade hats
